text: CURLY drops the photos on Gittes' desk. Curly towers over GITTES and sweats heavily through his workman's clothes, breathing progressively more labored. A drop plunks on Gi shiny desk top. Gittes notes it. A fan whiffs overhead. Gittes glances up it. He looks cool and brisk in a white linen suit despite the heat. Never taking his eyes off Curly, he lights a  cigarette using a lighter with a "nail" on his desk. Curly, with another anguished sob, turns and rams his fis into the wall, kicking the wastebasket as he does. He sta to sob again, slides along the wall where his fist has le a noticeable dent and its impact has sent the signed phot of several movie stars askew. Curly slides on into the blinds and sinks to his knees. H is weeping heavily now, and is in such pain that he actua bites into the blinds. Gittes doesn't move from his chair.
All right, enough is enough. You  can't eat the Venetian blinds, Curly.  I just had 'em installed on Wednesday.

Curly responds slowly, rising to his feet, crying. Gittes reaches into his desk and pulls out a shot glass, quickly selects a cheaper bottle of bourbon from several fifths o more expensive whiskeys. Gittes pours a large shot. He shoves the glass across his desk toward Curly.
Down the hatch.
Curly stares dumbly at it. Then picks it up, and drains i He sinks back into the chair opposite Gittes, begins to c quietly.
(drinking, relaxing a  little) She's just no good.
What can I tell you, Kid? You're  right. When you're right, you're  right, and you're right.
Ain't worth thinking about.
Gittes leaves the bottle with Curly.
You're absolutely right, I wouldn't  give her another thought.
(pouring himself) You know, you're okay, Mr. Gittes. I  know it's your job, but you're okay.
(settling back,  breathing a little  easier) Thanks, Curly. Call me Jake.
Thanks. You know something, Jake?
What's that, Curly?
I think I'll kill her.
Noticeably less plush than Gitte's. A well-groomed, dark- haired WOMAN sits nervously between their two desks, fidd with the veil on her pillbox hat.
I was hoping Mr. Gittes could see to  this personally.
(almost the manner of  someone comforting  the bereaved) If you'll allow us to complete our  preliminary questioning, by then  he'll be free.
There is the SOUND of ANOTHER MOAN coming from Gittes' Of Something made of glass shatters. The Woman grows more ed
Gittes and Curly stand in front of the desk, Gittes stari contemptuously at the heavy breathing hulk towering over  him. Gittes takes a handkerchief and wipes away the plunk perspiration on his desk.
(crying) They don't kill a guy for that.
Oh they don't?
Not for your wife. That's the  unwritten law.
Gittes pounds the photos on the desk, shouting;

I'll tell you the unwritten law, you  dumb son of a bitch, you gotta be  rich to kill somebody, anybody and  get away with it. You think you got  that kind of dough, you think you  got that kind of class?
Curly shrinks back a little.
You bet your ass you don't. You can't  even pay me off.
This seems to upset Curly even more.
I'll pay the rest next trip. We only  caught sixty ton of skipjack around  San Benedict. We hit a chubasco,  they don't pay you for skipjack the  way they do for tuna or albacore.
(easing him out of  his office) Forget it. I only mention it to  illustrate a point...
He's now walking him past SOPHIE who pointedly averts her gaze. He opens the door where on the pebbled glass can be read: "J. J. GITTES and Associates. DISCREET INVESTIGATIO
I don't want your last dime.
He throws an arm around Curly and flashes a dazzling smil
(continuing) What kind of guy do you think I am?
Thanks, Mr. Gittes.
Call me Jake. Careful driving home,  Curly.
He shuts the door on him and the smile disappears. He shakes his head, starting to swear under his breath.
A Mrs. Mulwray is waiting for you,  with Mr. Walsh and Mr. Duffy.
Gittes nods, walks on in.
Walsh rises when Gittes enters.
Mrs. Mulwray, may I present Mr.  Gittes?
Gittes walks over to her and again flashes a warm, sympat smile.
How do you do, Mrs. Mulwray?
Mr. Gittes...
Now, Mrs. Mulwray, what seems to be  the problem?
She holds her breath. The revelation isn't easy for her.
My husband, I believe, is seeing  another woman.
Gittes looks mildly shocked. He turns for confirmation to his two partners.
(gravely) No, really?
I'm afraid so.
I am sorry.
Gittes pulls up a chair sitting next to Mrs. Mulwray betw Duffy and Walsh. Duffy cracks his gum. Gittes gives him an irritated glance. Duffy stops chewing
Can't we talk about this alone, Mr.  Gittes?
I'm afraid not, Mrs. Mulwray. These  men are my operatives and at some  point they're going to assist me. I  can't do everything myself.
Of course not.
Now, what makes you certain he is  involved with someone?
Mrs. Mulwray hesitates. She seems uncommonly nervous at t question.
A wife can tell.
Gittes sighs.
Mrs. Mulwray, do you love your  husband?
(shocked) ...Yes of course.
(deliberately) Then go home and forget about it.
But...
(staring intently at  her) I'm sure he loves you, too. You know  the expression, let sleeping dogs  lie? You're better off not knowing.
(with some real anxiety) But I have to know.
Her intensity is genuine. Gittes looks to his two partner
All right, what's your husband's  first name?
Hollis. Hollis Mulwray.
(visibly surprised) Water and Power?
Mrs. Mulwray nods, almost shyly. Gittes is now casually b carefully checking out the detailing of Mrs. Mulwray's dr her handbag, shoes, etc.
He's the Chief Engineer.
(a little eagerly) Chief Engineer?
Gittes' glance tells Duffy Gittes wants to do the questio Mrs. Mulwray nods.
(confidentially) This type of investigation can be  hard on your pocketbook, Mrs. Mulwray.  It takes time.
Money doesn't matter to me, Mr.  Gittes.
Gittes sighs.
Very well. We'll see what we can do.
Already shimmering with heat. A drunk blows his nose with his fingers into the fountain the foot of the steps. Gittes, impeccably dressed, passes the drunk on the way u the stairs.
Former Mayor SAM BAGBY is speaking. Behind him is a huge  map, with overleafs and bold lettering: "PROPOSED ALTO VALLEJO DAM AND RESERVOIR"
Some of the councilmen are reading funny papers and gossi columns while Bagby is speaking.

Gentlemen, today you can walk out  that door, turn right, hop on a  streetcar and in twenty-five minutes  end up smack in the Pacific Ocean.  Now you can swim in it, you can fish  in it, you can sail in it but you  can't drink it, you can't water your  lawns with it, you can't irrigate an  orange grove with it.  Remember we  live next door to the ocean but we  also live on the edge of the desert.  Los Angeles is a desert community.  Beneath this building, beneath every  street there's a desert. Without  water the dust will rise up and cover  us as though we'd never existed! (pausing, letting the  implication sink in)
sitting next to some grubby farmers, bored. He yawns, edg away from one of the dirtier farmers.

(continuing) The Alto Vallejo can save us from  that, and I respectfully suggest  that eight and a half million dollars  is a fair price to pay to keep the  desert from our streets and not on  top of them.
An amalgam of farmers, businessmen, and city employees ha been listening with keen interest. A couple of the farmer applaud. Somebody shooshes them.
In a whispered conference.
(acknowledging Bagby) Mayor Bagby... let's hear from the  departments again. I suppose we better  take Water and Power first. Mr.  Mulwray.
Looking up with interest from his racing form.

Walks to the huge map with overleafs. He is a slender man his sixties, who wears glasses and moves with surprising  fluidity. He turns to a smaller, younger man, and nods. T man turns the overleaf on the map.

In case you've forgotten, gentlemen,  over five hundred lives were lost  when the Van der Lip Dam gave way  core samples have shown that beneath  this bedrock is shale similar to the  permeable shale in the Van der Lip  disaster.  It couldn't withstand  that kind of pressure there. (referring to a new  overleaf) Now you propose yet another dirt  banked terminus dam with slopes of  two and one half to one, one hundred  twelve feet high and a twelve thousand  acre water surface. Well, it won't  hold. I won't build it. It's that  simple. I am not making that kind of  mistake twice. Thank you, gentlemen.

Mulwray leaves the overleaf board and sits down. Suddenly there are some whoops and hollers from the rear of the  chambers and a redfaced FARMER drives in several scrawny, bleating sheep. Naturally, they cause a commotion.
(shouting to farmer) What in the hell do you think you're  doing? (as the sheep bleat  down the aisles toward  the Council) Get those goddam things out of here!
(right back) Tell me where to take them! You don't  have an answer for that so quick, do  you?
Bailiffs and sergeants-at-arms respond to the imprecation of the Council and attempt to capture the sheep and the  farmers, having to restrain one who looks like he's going bodily attack Mulwray.
(through above, to  Mulwray) You steal the water from the valley,  ruin the grazing, starve my livestock  who's paying you to do that, Mr.  Mulwray, that's what I want to know!

It's virtually empty. Sun blazes off it's ugly concrete b Where the banks are earthen, they are parched and choked  with weeds. After a moment, Mulwray's car pulls INTO VIEW on a flood  control road about fifteen feet above the riverbed. Mulwr gets out of the car. Me looks around.

Holding a pair of binoculars, downstream and just above t flood control road using some dried mustard weeds for cov He watches while Mulwray makes his way down to the center the riverbed. There Mulwray stops, tuns slowly, appears to be looking a the bottom of the riverbed, or at nothing at all.
Trains the binoculars on him. Sun glints off Mulwray's  glasses.
There's the SOUND of something like champagne corks poppi Then a small Mexican boy atop a swayback horse rides it i the riverbed, and into Gitte's view.

Himself stops, stands still when he hears the sound. Powe lines and the sun are overhead, the trickle of brackish w at his feet. He moves swiftly downstream in the direction of the sound toward Gittes.

Moves a little further back as Mulwray rounds the bend in the river and comes face to face with the Mexican boy on muddy banks. Mulwray says something to the boy. The boy doesn't answer at first. Mulwray points to the gr The boy gestures. Mulwray frowns. He kneels down in the m and stares at it. He seems to be concentrating on it. After a moment, he rises, thanks the boy and heads swiftl back upstream  scrambling up the bank to his car. There he reaches through the window and pulls out a roll blueprints or something like them. He spreads them on the hood of his car and begins to scribble some notes, lookin downstream from time to time. The power lines overhead HUM. He stops, listens to them then rolls up the plans and get back in the car. He drives off.
Hurries to get back to his car. He gets in and gets right back out. The steamy leather burns him. He takes a towel from the b seat and carefully places it on the front one. He gets in and takes off.
Street lights go on.
Pulls up, parks. Hurries out of the car, across the park  lawn and into the shade of some trees and buildings.

Pulls up, moves across the park at a different angle, but the direction Mulwray had gone. He makes it through the t in time to see Mulwray scramble adroitly down the side of the cliff to the beach below. Be seems in a hurry. Gittes moves after him, having a little more difficulty negotiat the climb than Mulwray did.

Gittes looks to his right where the bay is a long, clear  crescent. He looks to his left. There's a promontory of sorts. It's apparent Mulwray has gone that way. Gittes hesitates, the moves in that direction but climbs along the promontory i order to be above Mulwray.
Gittes spots Mulwray just below him, kicking at the sand. Mulwray picks up a starfish. Brushes the sand off it. Loo absently up toward Gittes.
Backs away, sits near the outfall, yawns.
Flashing in the dust.
Sitting, suddenly starts. He swears softly. He's in a pud of water and the seat of his trousers is wet.

Below him in watching the water trickling down from the  outfall near Gittes. Mulwray stands and stares at the water, apparently fascin Even as Gittes watches Mulwray watching, the volume and  velocity seem to increase until it gushes in spurts, casc into the sea, whipping it into a foam.
There's a slip of paper stuck under the windshield wiper. Gittes pulls it off, gets in the car and turns on the das light. It says:

head_text.subj: VOTE YES NOVEMBER 6... CITIZENS COMMITTEE TO SAVE OUR CIT

text: HON. SAM BAGBY, FORMER MAYOR  CHAIRMAN." Gittes grumbles, crumples it up and tosses it out the window. He notices o flyers parked on a couple of cars down the street. Gittes reaches down and opens his glove compartment.

Consists of a small mountain of Ingersoll pocket watches. The cheap price tags are still on them. Gittes pulls out  one. He absently winds it, checks the time with his own watch. It's 9:37 as he walks to Mulwray's car and places it behi the front wheel of Mulwray's car. He yawns again and head back to his own car.
Arrives whistling, opens the door with "J.J. GITTES AND  ASSOCIATES  DISCREET INVESTIGATION" on it.
Morning, Sophie.
Sophie hands him a small pile of messages. He goes throug them.
Walsh here?
He's in the dark room.
Gittes walks through his office to Duffy and Walsh's. A l red light is on in the corner, over a closed door. Gittes walks over and knocks on the door.
Where'd he go yesterday?
Three reservoirs. Men's room of a  Richfield gas station on Flower, and  the Pig 'n Whistle.
Jesus Christ, this guy's really got  water on the brain.
What'd you expect? That's his job.
Listen, we can't string this broad  out indefinitely we got to come up  with something.
I think I got something.
Oh yeah? You pick up the watch?
It's on your desk. Say, you hear the  one about the guy who goes to the  North Pole with Admiral Byrd looking  for penguins?
Gittes walks to his office.
Is the Ingersoll watch, the crystal broken, the hands sto at 2:47.
He was there all night.
Gittes drops it, sits down. Walsh comes in carrying a ser of wet photos stuck with clothes pins onto a small blackb
(continuing; eagerly) So what you got?
Walsh shows him the photos. He looks at them. They are a  series outside a restaurant showing Mulwray with another whose appearance is striking. In two of the photos a gnar cane is visible.
(continuing; obviously  annoyed) This?
They got into a terrific argument  outside the Pig 'n Whistle.
What about?
I don't know. The traffic was pretty  loud. I only heard one thing  apple  core.
Apple core?
(shrugs) Yeah.
Gittes tosses down the photos in disgust.
Jesus Christ, Walsh. That's what you  spent your day doing?
Look, you tell me to take pictures,  I take pictures.
Let me explain something to you,  Walsh. This business requires a  certain finesse.
The PHONE has been RINGING. Sophie buzzes him.
Yeah, Sophie? (he picks up the phone) Duffy, where are you?
Duffy's VOICE can be HEARD, excitedly. "I got it. I got i He's found himself some cute little twist in a rowboat, i Echo Park."
(continuing) Okay, slow down  Echo Park. (to Walsh) Jesus, water again.
Duffy is rowing, Gittes seated in the stern. They pass Mulwray and a slender blonde girl in a summer p dress, drifting in their rowboat, Mulwray fondly doting o the girl.
(to Duffy, as they  pass) Let's have a big smile, pal.
He shoots past Duffy, expertly running off a couple of fa shots. Mulwray and the girl seem blissfully unaware of them.
Turns again and they row past Mulwray and the girl, Gitte again clicking off several fast shots.

MOVE ALONG the red tiled roof and down to a lower level o the roof where Gittes' feet are hooked over the apex of t roof and Gittes himself is stretched face downward on the tiles, pointing himself and his camera to a veranda below him where the girl and Mulwray are eating. Gittes is clic off more shots when the tiles his feet are hooked over co loose. Gittes begins a slow slide down the tile to the edge of t roof and possibly over it to a three-story drop. He tries slow himself down. The loose tile also begins to slide. Gittes stops himself at the roof's edge by the storm drai and begins a very precarious turn, this time hooking his  feet in the drain itself. The loose tile falls and hits t veranda below. He stops as it's about to slide over the e He carefully lays it in the drain. But a fragment off the cracked edge of the tile falls.
Mulwray staring at the fragment at his feet. He looks to girl. He's clearly concerned. He rises, looks up to the roof.
The roof and the sign topping it betray nothing. He slowl sits back down, staring at the tile fragment.

head_text.subj: FUSE OVER CHIEF'S USE OF FUNDS FOR EL MACANDO LOVE NEST."

text: In the style of the Hearst yellow press, there is a heart shaped drawing around one of the photos that Gittes had t Next to it is a smaller column, "J.J. Gittes hired by  suspicious spouse."
Holds the paper and reads while getting his haircut and h shoes shined. In fact, almost all the customers are readi papers.
(to Gittes) When you get so much publicity, after  a while you must get blase about it.
A self-satisfied smile comes to Gittes' face.
(continuing) Face it. You're practically a movie  star.

In b.g., customers can be OVERHEARD talking about the dro Interspersed with above, someone is saying, "They're gonn start rationing water unless it rains." Someone else says "Only for washing your cars." Third says, "You're not goi to be able to water your lawn either, or take a bath more than once a week." First says, "If you don't have a lawn a car, do you get an extra bath?" Gittes has been staring outside the barbershop. A car is  stalled. The hood is up. A man watches his radiator boiling over.
(laughing) Look at that.
Heat's murder.
(end of conversation) Fools names and fools faces...
Gittes has heard the word. He straightens up.
(smiling; to Other  Customer) What's that, pal?
(indicating paper) Nothing. You got a hell of a way to  make a living.
Oh? What do you do to make ends meet?
Mortgage Department, First National  Bank.
Gittes laughs.
Tell me, how many people a week do  you foreclose on?
We don't publish a record in the  paper, I can tell you that.
Neither do I.
No, you have a press agent do it.
Gittes gets out of the chair. Barney, a little concerned, tries to restrain him, holding onto the barber sheet arou Gittes' neck.
Barney, who is this bimbo? He a  regular customer?
Take it easy, Jake.

Look, pal. I make an honest living.  People don't come to me unless they're  miserable and I help 'em out of a  bad situation. I don't kick them out  of their homes like you jerks who  work in the bank.
Jake, for Christ's sake.
Gittes is trying to take off his sheet.
C'mon, get out of the barber chair.  We'll go outside and talk this over.
The Customer is shrinking back into the chair.

Hey, c'mon, Jake. Sit down. Sit down.  You hear about the fella goes to his  friend and says, 'What'll I do, I'm  tired of screwing my wife?' and his  friend says, 'Whyn't you do what the  Chinese do?'
Gittes allows himself to be tugged back to his chair.
I don't know how that got in the  paper as a matter of fact  it  surprised me it was so quick. I make  an honest living.
'Course you do, Jake.
An honest living.
(continuing) So anyway, he says, 'whyn't you do  what the Chinese do?'
Gittes comes bursting in, slapping a newspapers on his th
Duffy, Walsh.
Walsh comes out of his office, Duffy out of the other one
(continuing) Sophie, go to the little girl's room  for a minute.
But, Mr. Gittes.
(insisting) Sophie.
Yes, Mr. Gittes.
She gets up and leaves.
So there's this fella who's tired of  screwing his wife.
Jake, listen.

Shut up, Duffy, you're always in a  hurry and his friend says why not do  what the Chinese do? So he says what  do they do? His friend says the  Chinese they screw for a while. Just  listen a second, Duffy...
A stunning YOUNG WOMAN appears behind Gittes in his doorw She's shortly joined by a small, GRAY-HAIRED MAN. They li unseen by Gittes.

(continuing) ...and then they stop and they read  a little Confucius and they screw  some more and they stop and they  smoke some opium and then they go  back and screw some more and they  stop again and they contemplate the  moon or something and it makes it  more exciting. So this other guy  goes home to screw his wife and after  a while he stops and gets up and  goes into the other room only he  reads Life Magazine and he goes back  and he screws some more and suddenly  says excuse me a second and he gets  up and smokes a cigarette and he  goes back and by this time his wife  is getting sore as hell. So he screws  some more and then he gets up to  look at the moon and his wife says,  'What the hell do you think you're  doing? (Gittes breaks up) ...you're screwing like a Chinaman.'

Gittes hangs onto Sophie's desk laughing his ass off. The little Gray-Haired Man winces. When Gittes looks up he se the Young Woman, apparently in her late twenties. She's s stunning that Gittes nearly gasps.
Mr. Gittes?
Yes?
Do you know me?
Well... I think I... I would've  remembered.
Have we ever met?
Well, no.
Never?
Never.
That's what I thought. You see, I'm  Mrs. Evelyn Mulwray. You know, Mr.  Mulwray's wife.
Gittes is staggered. He glances down at the newspaper.
Not that Mulwray?

Yes, that Mulwray, Mr. Gittes. And  since you agree with me we've never  met, you must also agree that I  haven't hired you to do anything.  Certainly not spy on my husband. I  see you like publicity, Mr. Gittes.  Well, you're going to get it.
Now wait a minute, Mrs. Mulwray...
She's walked past him toward the door. He stop her.
(continuing) ...there's some misunderstanding  here. It's not going to do any good  to get tough with me.
Evelyn flashes a cold smile.
I don't get tough with anybody, Mr.  Gittes.  My lawyer does.
Evelyn starts out the door and Gittes starts after her. T time he's stopped by the Gray-Haired Man who has also com out of his office and up behind him.
Here's something for you, Mr. Gittes.
Gittes turns to be handed a thick sheaf of papers, a summ and complaint. Evelyn walks out the door.
(continuing; pleasantly) I suppose we'll be hearing from your  attorney.
Gittes stares down at the papers in his hand.

On Gittes' desk. There are empty coffee cups, the summons and complaint, and the newspaper Gittes had brought with from the barber shop. The three men are sitting, worn and silent. Walsh chewing gum is the loudest noise in the room. Gittes looks to Walsh with obvious irritation. Walsh stop chewing. Duffy puts out a cigarette in the dregs of one of the cof cups.
(to Duffy) There's seven ashtrays in this room,  Duffy.
Okay.
That's a filthy habit.
I said okay, Jake.
Yeah, yeah. If she'd come in here  saying she was Shirley Temple you'd  say okay to that, too.
Look, Jake. She gave us Mulwray's  real phone number and address.
All she needed for that was the phone  book!
No, no. She said not to call, her  husband might answer.
When I find out who that phony bitch  was.
Gittes is staring down at the newspaper. He suddenly grab the phone, begins dialing. A tight little smile breaks ou on his face. He buzzes Sophie.
Sophie.
Yes, Mr. Gittes.

Get me the Times. Whitey Mehrholtz. (as he waits) And how about that snotty broad? (the phone to his ear) What does she think, she's perfect?  Coming in waving her lawyers and her  money at me  so goddam smug. She's  no better than anybody else in this  town.
Sophie BUZZES.

(continuing) Whitey, what's new, pal?... Yeah,  listen, where did you get those  photographs... Yeah, blowing a fuse  over the El Macando love nest.  That's  cute, Whitey... so who sent them to  you... I sent them? (Gittes laughs a little  hysterically) Why would I be asking how you got  them if I sent them?... Whitey?...  Whitey?... C'mon, level with me for  once, my tit's in the wringer and  it's beginning to hurt... yeah...   yeah... yeah.
He hangs up.
So he says you sent them?
(after a moment) They're all a bunch of phonies.
Gittes stops outside a door marked: "HOLLIS J. MULWRAY CHIEF ENGINEER"
He enters an outer office. The SECRETARY looks surprised.
Mr. Mulwray, please.
He's not in, Mr.?
Gittes.
May I ask what this is regarding?
It's personal. Has he been out long?
Since lunch.
Gee whiz. (he glances at his  watch) And I'm late.
He was expecting you?
Fifteen minutes ago. Why don't I go  in and wait?
Without waiting for a response, he does. The Secretary ha rises in protest but Gittes is through the inner door.

The walls are covered with commendation, photos of Mulwra at various construction sites, large maps of watershed ar and reservoirs in the city. On the desk is a framed, tint photo of Evelyn in riding clothes. Gittes moves to the desk, watching the translucent pane i the upper half of the door leading to the outer office as does. He begins to open and close the desk drawers after quickl examining the top. He tries one of the drawers and it doe open. He reopens the top drawer, and the bottom one opens. He looks in it, pulls out a checkbook. He opens it, riffl through the stubs like he was shuffling cards. Drops it,  finds a set of keys, an old phone book, and a menu from a Water Department lunch at the Biltmore Hotel in 1913. The He flips through them, reads one notation in Mulwray's ne hand: "Tues. night. Oak Pass Res. 7 channels used."

Gittes spots a shadow looming in front of the translucent pane. He quickly tosses item after item back, kneeing the drawer, nearly knocking a spare pair of Mulwray's glasses off the desk top when he does. He catches them, puts them the desk and is pacing the room as the door opens.
Enters the room. An anxious Secretary is right behind him
Can I help you? (extending his hand) Russ Yelburton, Deputy Chief in the  Department.
(equally pleasant) J.J. Gittes. And it's not a  departmental matter.
I wonder if you'd care to wait in my  office?
This is more a request than an invitation. Gittes nods,  follows Yelburton out, through the outer office to his of down the hall.
(continuing; as they're  going) You see, this whole business in the  paper with Mr. Mulwray has us all on  edge.

Smaller than Mulwray's, he has most noticeably a lacquere marlin mounted on the wall. There are a couple of other  pictures of Yelburton with yellowtail and other fish he's standing beside. There's also a small burgee of a fish with the initials A below it, tacked onto the wall.
After all, you work with a man for a  certain length of time, you come to  know him, his habits, his values,  and so forth. Well either he's the  kind who chases after women or he  isn't.
And Mulwray isn't?
He never even kids about it.
Maybe he takes it very seriously.
Gittes winks. Yelburton chuckles appreciatively, loosenin up a little.
You don't happen to know where Mr.  Mulwray's having lunch?
I'm sorry, I --
Well, tell him I'll be back.
Gittes spots a card tray on Yelburton's desk.
(continuing) Mind if I take one of your cards?   In case I want to get in touch with  you again.
Help yourself.

Gittes fishes a couple off the tray, puts them in his  handkerchief pocket. He goes out the door, nearly running into a man who is standing by the Secretary's desk, about GITTES' age only a head taller and a foot wider, dressed a plain suit that fits him about as well as a brown paper bag.
Mulvihlll, what are you doing here?

head_text.subj: OUTER OFFICE YELBURTON, MULVIHILL AND GITTES

text: Mulvihill stares at Gittes with unblinking eyes, remains the desk.
They shut my water off, what's it to  you?
How'd you find out? You don't drink  it, you don't take a bath in it,  maybe they sent you a letter. Ah,  but then you'd have to be able to  read.
Mulvihill moves toward Gittes, shaking with fury. Yelburt steps between them.
(continuing) Relax, Mulvihill, glad to see you. (to Yelburton) Do you know Claude Mulvihill here?
Hope so. He's working for us.
Rings the bell. He waits. A powerful CHINESE BUTLER with heavy hair and a half-jack of gold on one front tooth, answers the door.
J.J. Gittes to see Mr. Mulwray.

He hands the Chinese Butler a card from his wallet. The B takes it and disappears, leaving Gittes standing in the  doorway. Gittes stands, and sweats, watching a Japanese GARDENER t a hedge. There's a SQUEAKING SOUND. Gittes moves a few fe off the porch.
A chauffeur is washing down a cream-colored Packard with chamois. Steam rises off the hood. The squeaking has obviously com from the chamois.
In doorway.
Please.
Gittes looks behind him. The Chinese Butler is gesturing him to follow.
Follows him, trying to check out the rooms as he goes. A  maid is cleaning in the den. They pass through it out som French doors along a trellised walkway to a large pond wi running water.
You wait, please.

Gittes is left standing by the pond. It's suddenly very q except for the runnning water. The pond is over-flowing.  After a moment, the Gardener comes running back. He smile at Gittes, probes into the pond. There's something gleaming in the bottom of it. Gittes no it. After a moment, the Gardener drops the long probe, the wa recede.

head_text.subj: EXT. POND GITTES AND JAPANESE GARDENER DAY

text: (to Gittes) Bad for glass.
(not understanding) Yeah sure. Bad for glass.

The Gardener nods, and is off, leaving Gittes staring at object in the bottom of the pond that is gleaming. He looks at the tool the Gardener was using, hesitates, p it up and starts to probe into the pond himself, toward t gleaming object. He then spots Evelyn rounding a turn, coming down the  trellised pathway. He casually belts the probe, holds ont it for poise. Evelyn is wearing jeans that are lathered white on the in of the thighs and laced with brown horsehair. She's wearing riding boots, is perspiring a little, but l younger than she did in the office.
Yes, Mr. Gittes?
Gittes is a little taken aback at seeing Evelyn. He is an as well. Nevertheless, he is elaborately polite.
Actually, I'm here to see your  husband, Mrs. Mulwray.
He laughs. a little nervously. He waits for a reply. Ther is none. The Chinese Butler appears on the veranda.
Would you like something to drink?
What are you having?
Iced tea.
Yeah. Fine, thank you.
Chinese Butler nods, disappears

head_text.subj: EXT. POND AND GARDEN MULWRAY HOUSE DAY

text: Evelyn sits at a glass-topped table. Gittes Joins her.
My husband's at the office.
Actually he's not. And he's moved  from his apartment at the El Macando.
(sharply) That's not his apartment.
Anyway... I... the point is, Mrs.  Mulwray.  I'm not in business to be  loved, but I am in business, and  believe me, whoever set up your  husband, set me up. L.A.'s a small  town, people talk.
He waits for a response. Then:
(continuing; uneasily) I'm just trying to make a living,  and I don't want to become a local  Joke.
Mr. Gittes, you've talked me into  it. I'll drop the lawsuit.
What?
I said I'll drop it.
The iced tea comes on a tray which Ramon sets down betwee them.
(continuing; pleasantly) So let's just drop the whole thing.  Sugar?  Lemon?
Mrs. Mulwray?
(as she's mixing one  of the drinks) Yes, Mr. Gittes?
I don't want to drop it.
Evelyn looks up. Gittes smiles a little sheepishly.
I should talk this over with your  husband.
(a little concerned) Why?... What on earth for?  Look,  Hollis seems to think you're an  innocent man.
Well, I've been accused of many  things, Mrs. Mulwray, but never that.
Again he laughs a little nervously. Again no reaction.

(continuing) You see, somebody went to a lot of  trouble here, and I want to find  out, lawsuit or no lawsuit. I'm not  the one who's supposed to be caught  with my pants down... so I'd like to  see your husband. Unless that's a  problem.
(with a slight edge) What do you mean?
May I speak frankly, Mrs. Mulwray?
You may if you can, Mr. Gittes.
(determined to be  polite) Well, that little girlfriend, she  was attractive in a cheap sort of  way of course.  She's disappeared.  Maybe they disappeared together  somewhere.
(with rising anger) Suppose they did. How does it concern  you?
Nothing personal, Mrs. Mulwray, I  just --
It's very personal. It couldn't be  more personal. Is this a business or  an obsession with you?

Look at it this way. Now this phony  broad, excuse the language, says  she's you, she's hired me. Whoever  put her up to it, didn't have anything  against me. They were out to get  your husband. Now if I see him, I  can help him.  Did you talk this  morning?
Evelyn brushes lightly at the horsehair on her Jeans.
No. I went riding rather early.
Looks like you went quite a distance.
No, Just riding bareback, that's  all. Anyway, you might try the Oak  Pass or Stone Canyon Reservoirs.  Sometimes at lunch Hollis takes walks  around them. Otherwise he'll be home  by 6:30.
I'll stop by.
Please call first.
Gittes nods.
Gittes drives up a winding road, following a flood channe up into the parched hills.

One a rescue truck, are at the entrance to the reservoir. The chain link fence with its KEEP OUT sign is open and t are people milling around. The reservoir is below. Gittes' car is stopped by a couple of UNIFORMED POLICE.
Sorry, this is closed to the public,  sir.
Gittes hesitates only a moment, then:
(to the Guard) It's all right. Russ Yelburton, Deputy  Chief in the Department.
He fishes out one of Yelburton's cards from his handkerch pocket, hands it to the Guard.
Sorry, Mr. Yelburton. Go on down.

Gittes drives past the Guards, through the gate, along th reservoir. He spots a police car and an unmarked one as w Gittes stops and gets out of the car. Several men with th backs turned, one talking quietly, staring down into the  reservoir where other men in small skiffs are apparently  dredging for something. One of the men turns and sees Gittes. He recognizes Gitte and is visibly shocked.
Gittes, for Chrissakes.
Loach.
(moving to Gittes,  taking him by the  arm) C'mon, get out of here before --
Loach tries to ease him down the path.
Before what? What the hell's going  on?

At the sound of his raised voice, a man standing at the e of the channel, talking to two boys in swimming trunks, t around. He's a tall, sleek Mexican in his early thirties, LUIS ESCOBAR. Both Gittes and Escobar register considerable surprise at seeing one another. The men around them are extremely une Loach is actually sweating. Finally, Escobar smiles.
Hello, Jake.
(without smiling) How are you, Lou?
I have a cold I can't seem to shake  but other than that, I'm fine.
Summer colds are the worst.
Yeah, they are.
Gittes reaches into his pocket, pulls out his cigarette c
No smoking, sir. It's a fire hazard  this time of year.
I think we can make an exception.  I'll see he's careful with the  matches.
(lighting up) Thanks, Lou.
How'd you get past the guards?
Well, to tell you the truth, I lied  a little.
Escobar nods. They walk a couple of steps. The other poli two plainclothesmen and a uniformed officer, watch them.
You've done well by yourself.
I get by.
Well, sometimes it takes a while for  a man to find himself and I guess  you have.
Poking around in other people's dirty  linen.
Yeah. Tell me, you still throw  Chinamen into jail for spitting on  the laundry?
You're behind the times, Jake. They've  got steam irons now. (smiles) And I'm out of Chinatown.
Since when?
Since I made Lieutenant.
It's apparent Gittes is impressed despite himself.
Congratulations.
Uh-huh. So what are you doing here?
Looking for someone.
Who?
Hollis Mulwray. You seen him?
Oh yes.
I'd like to talk to him.
You're welcome to try. There he is.

Escobar points down to the reservoir. A couple of men usi poles with hooks are fishing about in the water. It can b SEEN that one of them has hooked something. He shouts. The other man hooks it, too. They pull, reveal the soaking back of a man's coat. They start to pull the  body into the skiff.

Are standing over the body of Mulwray. Escobar has the sh drawn back. Evelyn nods. Escobar drops the sheet. Escobar and Evelyn move a few fe to one side and whisper, almost as though they were tryin to keep the corpse from hearing them.
It looks like he was washed the entire  length of the runoff channel. Could  he swim?
Of course.
Obviously the fall must have knocked  him out.
Evelyn nods slightly Escobar coughs. A coroner's assistan wheels the body out of the office.
(continuing) This alleged affair he was having.  The publicity didn't make him morose  or unhappy?
Gittes has been sitting on a wooden bench, smoking and  listening. At this question, he rises and looks through t doorway. Escobar sees him, ignores him. Evelyn doesn't see him.
...Well, it didn't make him happy...
But there is no possibility he would  have taken his own life?
(sharply) No.
(a little uncomfortably  now) Mrs. Mulwray, do you happen to know  the name of the young woman in  question?
Evelyn shows a flash of annoyance.
No.
Do you know where she might be?
Certainly not!
Escobar and Evelyn move slowly toward the door.
You and your husband never discussed  her?
(stopping, faltering) He... we did... he wouldn't tell me  her name.  We quarreled over her...  of course. It came as a complete  surprise to me.
A complete surprise?
Yes.
But I thought you'd hired a private  investigator.
A private investigator?
(gesturing vaguely  toward the door) Mr. Gittes.
Well yes.
Evelyn looks up to see Gittes standing in the doorway onl foot or two from her. She stops cold. They look at one an for a long moment.
(her eyes on Gittes) But I... I... did that because I  thought it was a nasty rumor I'd put  an end to...
She finishes, looks plaintively at Gittes. Escobar is rig at her back. Gittes says nothing.
And when did Mr. Gittes inform you  that these rumors had some foundation  in fact?
Evelyn looks at Escobar but doesn't know how to answer hi
(smoothly) Just before the story broke in the  papers, Lou.
Escobar nods. They begin to walk slowly, again have to mo out of the way as some other corpse is being wheeled out one of the Coroner cubicles.
You wouldn't happen to know the  present whereabouts of the young  woman.
No.
Or her name?
No.
They have walked a few steps further down the hall.
Will you need me for anything else,  Lieutenant?
I don't think so, Mrs. Mulwray. Of  course you have my deepest sympathy  and if we need anymore information,  we'll be in touch.
I'll walk her to her car, be right  back.

Evelyn glances at Gittes. They go through a couple of out doors and pass several reporters who have been in the out hall, laughing, kidding, the tag end of lines like "only L.A." and "Southern Cafeteria." Gittes hurries her past the reporters who flank them, ask questions. Gittes brushes them aside.

head_text.subj: EVELYN AND GITTES AT HER CAR

text: In a small parking lot. Evelyn fumbles in her bag, looking feverishly for somethi in her purse.
Mrs. Mulwray?... Mrs. Mulwray.
(flushed, perspiring) ...Just a minute...
(touching her gently) You left your keys in the ignition.
Oh... thank you.
She glances down, leans against the side of the car.
(continuing) Thank you for going along with me. I  just didn't want to explain  anything... I'll send you a check.
(puzzled) A check?
Evelyn gets in her car.
To make it official, I hired you.
She drives off, leaving Gittes gaping.
Don't give me that, Lou. You hauled  me down here for a statement.
Escobar shrugs.
I don't want it anymore.
No?
No. It was an accident.
You mean that's what you're going to  call it.
Escobar looks up.
That's right. (contemptuously) Out of respect for his civic position.
Resume walking. Gittes laughs.
What'd he do, Lou, make a pass at  your sister?
Escobar stops.

No, he drowned a cousin of mine with  about five hundred other people. But  they weren't very important, just a  bunch of dumb Mexicans living by a  dam. Now beat it, Gittes, you don't  come out of this smelling like a  rose, you know.
Oh yeah? Can you think of something  to charge me with?
When I do, you'll hear about it.
Gittes nods, turns, and walks down the hall.

Gittes stops by a body on the table, the toe tagged with  Mulwray's name. MORTY is standing near it in a doorway to adjoining room. A RADIO is on, and with it the announceme that they're about to hear another chapter in the life of Lorenzo Jones and his devoted wife, Belle. Another Corone assistant sits at the table, listening to the radio and e a sandwich. Gittes ambles into the room.
(a cigarette dangling  out of his mouth) Jake, what're you doin' here?
Nothin', Morty, it's my lunch hour,  I thought I'd drop by and see who  died lately.
Gittes picks up the sheet and pulls it back. CAMERA GETS FIRST GLIMPSE of Mulwray's body. Eyes open, the face badl cut and bruised.
Yeah? Ain't that something? Middle  of a drought, the water commissioner  drowns. Only in L.A.
(looking at. Mulwray) Yeah. Banged up pretty bad.
That's a long fall.
So how are you, Morty?
Morty is wheeling in another body with the help of an  assistant.
Never better. You know me, Jake.
As he begins to move the body into the refrigerator, he b into a wrenching spasm of coughing. Gittes spots the othe body, lowers the sheet on Mulwray.
(picking up on cough) Yeah, so who you got there?
Morty pulls back the sheet.
Leroy Shuhardt, local drunk used to  hang around Ferguson's Alley.
Morty brushes some sand from the man's face, laughs.
(continuing) Quite a character. Lately he'd been  living in one of the downtown storm  drains. Had a bureau dresser down  there and everything.
Gittes has already lost interest. He starts away.
Yeah.
Drowned, too.
This stops Gittes.
Come again?
Yeah, got dead drunk, passed out in  the bottom of the riverbed.
The L.A. River?
(a little puzzled) Yeah, under Hollenbeck Bridge, what's  wrong with that?
Gittes has moved back to the body, looks at it more close
It's bone dry, Morty.
It's not completely dry.
Yeah, well he ain't gonna drown in a  damp riverbed either, I don't care  how soused he was. That's like  drowning in a teaspoon.
Morty shrugs.
We got water out of him, Jake. He  drowned.
Gittes walks away mumbling.
Jesus, this town...
He's parked on an overpass. The sign HOLLENBECK BRIDGE on one of its concrete columns. Gittes looks down into the  riverbed below.

Gittes can see the muddy remains of a collapsed shack, it contents strewn down river from the bridge. Below him, ly half over the storm drain and one wall that was on the ba of the river is a sign that proclaims "OWN YOUR OWN OFFIC IN THIS BUILDING $5000 to $6000" which was used as a roof sorts. Downstream, there's the dresser, an oil drum, a Fo seat cushion, an Armour lard can, etc. The trashy remains Shuhardt's home. Gittes scrambles down the embankment and as he lands near the storm drain one shoe sinks, ankle deep into mud. Gitt pulls it out, swearing. He begins to walk a little further downstream when he hea the vaguely familiar SQUISHY CLOP of something. Clearing the bridge on the opposite side is the little Me Boy, again on his swayback horse, riding along the muddy  bank. They look at one another a moment.
(calling out to him) You were riding here the other day,  weren't you...?
The Boy doesn't answer.
(continuing) Speak English?... Habla Ingles?
(finally) Si.
Didn't you talk to a man here... few  days ago... wore glasses... he...
The Boy nods.
(continuing) What did you talk about, mind my  asking?
The shadows of the two are very long now.
(finally) The water.
What about the water?
When it comes.
When it comes? What'd you tell him?
Comes in different parts of the river.  Every night a different part.
Gittes nods. The horse snorts. The Boy rides slowly on.
Gittes scrambles up the embankment to note the direction storm drain by Hollenbeck Bridge takes. It is headed abov toward the Hollywood Hills, where the sun is setting.
Winding his way up a section of the Hollywood Hills. He p up on an open flood channel with the spotlight by the dri windwing.
Along the flood channel. It is dark now and Gittes follow the channel with the car spotlight. He turns at a fork in the road which allows him to continue following the flood channel.
The road is narrower. Gittes drives more slowly. Foliage overgrown in the channel so its bottom cannot be glimpsed
The road is dirt. Heavy clusters of oak trees and eucalyp are everywhere. It is very still. Another turn and a pie- shaped view of a lake of lights in the city below can be  GLIMPSED.
Over the road, bolted. It says "OAK PASS RESERVOIR. KEEP

The chain-link itself actually extends over the flood cha and down into it, making access along the channel itself  impossible. Gittes backs up, turns off the motor, the car lights, the spotlight. A lone light overhead on tension wires is the sole  illumination. There is only the eerie SOUND of the tension WIRES HUMMIN Gittes gets out of the car, clubs the fence near the Floo channel itself.

Gittes carefully works his way up through the thick Folia toward a second and large chain-link fence. Lights from t reservoir still higher above can be SEEN. Suddenly there is a GUNSHOT. Then ANOTHER. Gittes dives i the flood control channel, which is at this point about f feet deep and six feet wide. There is the SOUND of men  scurrying through the brush, coming near him, then retrea Gittes loses himself among the ivy in the channel. He waits. The men seem to have passed him by. But there i another SOUND now. An echoing growing sound. It puzzles  Gittes. He starts to lift his head to catch the direction

head_text.subj: GITTES IN FLOOD CONTROL CHANNEL NIGHT

text: Then he's inundated with a rush of water which pours over him, knocks off his hat, carries him down the channel, ba into its banks, as he desperately tries to grab some of t overgrowth to hang on and pull himself out. But the force the stream batters him and carries him with it until he's brought rudely to the chainlink fence. It stops him cold. He's nearly strained through it. Swearing and choking, he pulls himself out of the rushing water by means of the fence itself. Drenched, battered, he slowly climbs back over the fence makes his way toward his car.
He fishes for his car keys, looks down. One shoe is missi
(grumbling) Goddam Florsheim shoe, goddammit.

He starts to get into his car but Mulvihill and a SMALLER MAN stop him. Mulvihill pulling his coat down and pinning his arms, holding him tightly. The smaller man thrusts a  switchblade knife about an inch and a half up Gittes' lef nostril.
(shaking with emotion) Hold it there, kitty cat.
Frozen, the knife in his nostril, the street lamp overhea gleaming on the silvery blade.
You are a very nosey fellow, kitty  cat... you know what happens to nosey  fellows?
The Smaller Man actually seems to be trembling with rage  when he says this. Gittes doesn't move.
(continuing) Wanna guess? No? Okay, lose their  noses.

With a quick flick the Smaller Man pulls back on the blad laying Gittes' left nostril open about an inch further. G screams. Blood gushes down onto his shirt and coat. Gittes bends over, instinctively trying to keep the blood from getting on his clothes. Mulvihill and the Smaller Ma stare at him.
(continuing) Next time you lose the whole thing,  kitty cat. I'll cut it off and feed  it to my goldfish, understand?
Tell him you understand, Gittes.
Gittes is now groveling on his hands and knees.
(mumbling) I understand...
Gittes on the ground can see only his tormentor's two-ton brown and white wing-tipped shoes, lightly freckled with blood.
Comes up and lightly shoves Gittes into the ground. The S of FOOTSTEPS RETREATING, Gittes gasping.
Sits behind his desk, BACK TO CAMERA, not moving. Duffy s staring at nothing, Walsh moves uneasily around the room. The PHONE is RINGING. Sophie BUZZES.
(pressing down intercom) Yeah, Sophie.
A Miss Sessions calling.
Who?
Ida Sessions.
Don't know her. Take a number.
A bandage spread-eagled across Gittes' nose.
So some contractor wants to build a  dam and he makes a few payoffs. So  what?
Gittes turns slowly to Walsh. He lightly taps his nose.
(continuing) Think you can nail Mulvihill? They'll  claim you were trespassing.
I don't want Mulvihill.  I want the  big boys that are making the payoffs.
Then what'll you do?
Sue the shit out of 'em.
Yeah?

Yeah. What's wrong with you guys?  Think ahead. We find 'em, sue 'em.  We'll make a killing. (a dazzling smile) We'll have dinner at Chasen's twice  a week, we'll be pissing on ice the  rest of our lives.
Sue people like that they're liable  to be having dinner with the Judge  who's trying the suit.
Gittes looks irritated. The PHONE RINGS again.
Miss Ida Sessions again. She says  you know her.
Okay.
Gittes picks up the phone. He winks to his boys.
(continuing) Hello, Miss Sessions. I don't believe  we've had the pleasure.
Oh yes we have... are you alone, Mr.  Gittes?
(clowning a little  for the boys) Isn't everybody? What can I do for  you, Miss Sessions?
Walsh promptly starts to tell Duffy the Admiral Byrd stor
Well, I'm a working girl, Mr. Gittes.  I didn't come in to see you on my  own.
When did you come in?
I was the one who pretended to be  Mrs. Mulwray, remember?
Walsh has finished off the punch line and both men are  laughing raucously. Gittes drops the mail he's been loafi through and puts his hand over the receiver.
(to Duffy and Walsh) Shut the fuck up! (then back to Ida) ...Yes I remember nothing, Miss  Sessions, just going over a detail  or two with my associates... you  were saying?
Well I never expected anything to  happen like what happened to Mr.  Mulwray, the point is if it ever  comes out I want somebody to know I  didn't know what would happen.
I understand... if you could tell me  who employed you, Miss Sessions.  That could help us both.
Oh no.
...Why don't you give me your address  and we can talk this over?
No, Mr. Gittes. Just look in the  obituary column of today's Times...
The obituary column?
You'll find one of those people.
'Those people?' Miss Sessions.
She hangs up. Gittes looks to his two men.

Gittes is seated, flips through the paper until he finds OBITUARY COLUMN, scans it, looks up, abruptly tears the c from the paper and puts it in his pocket. When he closes the paper we can SEE headlines in the left hand column: "WATER BOND ISSUE PASSES COUNCIL". Ten milli dollar referendum to go before the public. Evelyn Mulwray is standing at the table as he does so. He rises, allows her to sit.
Gittes watches her as she removes her gloves slowly... Sh wearing dove gray gabardine, subdued, tailored.
Thanks for coming... drink?
The waiter's appeared. Evelyn is looking at Gittes' nose.
Tom Collins with lime, not lemon,  please.

Evelyn looks down and smoothes her gloves. When she looks back up she stares expectantly at Gittes. Gittes pulls out a torn envelope. The initials ECM can be SEEN in a delicate scroll on the corner of it.
I got your check in the mall.
Yes. As I said, I was very grateful.
Gittes' fingers the envelope. He coughs.
Mrs. Mulwray, I'm afraid that's not  good enough.
(a little embarrassed) Well, how much would you like?
Stop it. The money's fine. It's  generous but you've shortchanged me  on the story.
(coolly) I have?
I think so. Something besides your  husband's death was bothering you.  You were upset but not that upset.
Mr. Gittes... (icily) Don't tell me how I feel.
The drinks come. The waiter sets them down.
Sorry. Look, you sue me, your husband  dies, you drop the lawsuit like a  hot potato, and all of it quicker  than wind from a duck's ass. Excuse  me. Then you ask me to lie to the  police.
It wasn't much of a lie.
If your husband was killed it was. (meaning check) This can look like you paid me off  to withhold evidence.
But he wasn't killed.
Gittes smiles.
I think you're hiding something,  Mrs. Mulwray.
Evelyn remains unperturbed.
Well, I suppose I am... actually I  knew about the affair.
How did you find out?
My husband.
He told you?
Evelyn nods.
(continuing) And you weren't the slightest bit  upset about it?
I was grateful.
Evelyn for the first time appears a little embarrassed.
You'll have to explain that, Mrs.  Mulwray.
Why?
(a flash of annoyance) Look, I do matrimonial work, It's my  metiay.  When a wife tells me she's  happy her husband is cheating on her  it runs contrary to my experience.
Gittes looks significantly to Evelyn.
Unless what?
(looking directly at  her) She's cheating on him.
Evelyn doesn't reply.
(continuing) Were you?
Evelyn is clearly angry but she is controlling it.
I don't like the word 'cheat.'
Did you have affairs?
(flashing) Mr. Gittes.
Did he know?
(almost an outburst) Well I wouldn't run home and tell  him whenever I went to bed with  someone, if that's what you mean.
This subdues Gittes a little. Evelyn is still a little he
(continuing; more  calmly) Is there anything else you want to  know?
Where you were when your husband  died.
I can't tell you.
You mean you don't know where you  were?
I mean I can't tell you.
You were seeing someone, too.
Evelyn looks squarely at him. She doesn't deny it.
For very long?

I don't see anyone for very long,  Mr. Gittes.  It's difficult for me.  Now I think you know all you need to  about me. I didn't want publicity. I  didn't want to go into any of this,  then or now. Is this all?
Gittes nods.
Oh, by the way. What's the 'C' stand  for?
He's been fingering the envelope...
(she stammers slightly) K... Cross.
That your maiden name?
Yes... why?
No reason.
Evelyn turns into Gittes.
You must've had a reason to ask me  that.
(shrugs) No. I'm just a snoop.
You seem to have had a reason for  every other question.
No, not for that one.
I don't believe you.
Gittes suddenly turns sharply in to Evelyn.
(moving in) Do me a favor. Sit still and act  like I'm charming.
Evelyn involuntarily draws back.
(continuing) There's somebody here. Say something. Anything. Something like we're being  intimate.
Evelyn reluctantly allows Gittes to move closer and dangl his hand in front of their faces. She stares at him.
(meaning his nose) How did it happen?
(quietly) Been meaning to talk to you about  that.
(quietly) Maybe putting your nose in other  people's business?
(quietly) More like other people putting their  business in my nose.
Evelyn actually smiles a little.
You son of a bitch.
Gittes looks up and flashes his smile.
Mrs. Match. How're you?
MRS. MATCH is swaying over the table, a plump woman with glass of whiskey in one hand, a large purse in the other, and a menacing look in her eye.
Don't give me that, you son of a  bitch.
Okay.
Gittes turns back to Evelyn.
(softly) Another satisfied client?
Another satisfied client's wife.
Look at me, you son of a bitch. You...  you bastard. Are you happy, are you  happy now?
She tries to take a swipe at Gittes with her purse. Gitte covers himself. Waiters rush over.
You smug son of a bitch. My husband's  so upset he sweats all night! How do  you think that makes me feel?
Sweaty?

Mrs. Match swings at Gittes again and again. She catches on the nose. It hurts. He covers it, then swings his leg from under the table and deftly kicks her in the shin. Mrs. Match drops her purse and spills her drink. She grab her shin, hopping around a little. The waiters who had tr to restrain her now try to keep her from falling over.
Let's get out of here before she  picks up her purse.
They rise and move toward the door.
(quietly) Tough guy, huh?
Gittes looks, sees she's kidding, and nods.

head_text.subj: OUTSIDE IN THE PARKING LOT DUSK

text: Gittes' car has been brought by the parking attendant. Th attendant opens the passenger side for Evelyn.
Oh, no. I've got my own car. The  creamcolored Packard.
(to attendant who  dutifully starts for  her car) Wait a minute, sonny. (to Evelyn) I think you better come with me.
What for? There's nothing more to  say. (to attendant) Get my car, please.
The attendant starts after it again. Gittes leans on the  open door of his car and in to Evelyn. He talks quietly b spits it out.

Okay, go home. But in case you're  interested your husband was murdered.  Somebody's dumping tons of water out  of the city reservoirs when we're  supposedly in the middle of a drought,  he found out, and he was killed.  There's a waterlogged drunk in the  morgue. Involuntary manslaughter if  anybody wants to take the trouble  which they don't. It looks like half  the city is trying to cover it all  up, which is fine with me. But, Mrs.  Mulwray. (now inches from her) I goddam near lost my nose! And I  like it. I like breathing through  it. And I still think you're hiding  something.
Evelyn steadies herself on the open car door. She stares Gittes for a long moment. Then he gently tugs the car doo closed.
Mr. Gittes.
He drives off into the Wilshire traffic, leaving Evelyn  looking after him.
"HOLLIS I. MULWRAY CHIEF ENGINEER"
Gittes goes through the door to the Secretary. She looks She recognizes Gittes again and is not happy to see him.
J.J. Gittes to see Mr. Yelburton.

The Secretary immediately gets up and goes into the inner office. Gittes turns and strolls around the office a moment. He s a photographic display of "THE HISTORY OF THE DWP. THE EA YEARS", along the wall. He stops as he spots a photo of t man with the cane Gittes had seen photos of earlier. He i standing high in the mountains, near a pass. The caption  reads "JULIAN CROSS. 1905". Cross is strikingly handsome. Gittes immediately pulls out the envelope containing Evel check. He looks at the corner of it, his thumb pressing d under the middle initial C, then he looks back to the pho The Secretary returns.
Mr. Yelburton will be busy for some  time.
Well I'm on my lunch hour. I'll wait.
He's liable to be tied up  indefinitely.
I take a long lunch. All day  sometimes.
Gittes pulls out a cigarette case, offers the Secretary o She refuses. He lights up and begins to hum 'The Way You  Look Tonight,' strolling along the wall looking at more  photographs.
Here he spots several photos of a much younger Mulwray, a with Julian Cross. One of the captions: "HOLLIS MULWRAY A

head_text.subj: JULIAN CROSS AS THE AQUEDUCT CLEARS THE SANTA SUSANNAH PA

text: Gittes, still humming, turns to the Secretary.
Julian Cross worked for the water  department?
(looking up) Yes. No.
(humming, then) He did or he didn't?
He owned it.
Gittes is genuinely surprised at this.
He owned the water department?
Yes.
He owned the entire water supply for  the city?
Yes.
(really surprised) How did they get it away from him?
(a sigh, then) Mr. Mulwray felt the public should  own the display. The water. If you'll  just read the display.
(glances back, hums,  then) Mulwray? I thought you said Cross  owned the department.
Along with Mr. Mulwray.
They were partners.
(testily) Yes. Yes, they were partners.

She gets up, annoyed, and goes into Yelburton's inner off Gittes goes back to the photographs. He hears a SCRATCHIN SOUND, apparently coming from just outside the outer door He moves quickly to it, hesitates, swiftly opens the door Workmen are behind it, scraping away Mulwray's name on th outer door, looking up at Gittes in some surprise. The Secretary returns, sees the workman on the floor.
(to Gittes) Mr. Yelburton will see you now.
Gittes nods graciously, heads on into Yelburton's office.
There is a subtle but perceptible difference in Yelburton attitude. He's now head of the department.
Mr. Gittes, sorry to keep you waiting.  These staff meetings, they just go  on and on.
Yeah, must be especially tough to  take over under these circumstances.
Oh yes. Hollis was the best department  head the city's ever had. My goodness,  what happened to your nose?
(smiles) I cut myself shaving.
You ought to be more careful. That  must really smart.
Only when I breathe.
(laughing) Only when you breathe... don't tell  me you're still working for Mrs.  Mulwray?
I never was.
(stops smiling) I don't understand.
Neither do I, actually. But you hired  me or you hired that chippie to hire  me.
Mr. Gittes, you're not making a bit  of sense.

Well, look at it this way, Mr.  Yelburton.  Mulwray didn't want to  build a dam and he had a reputation  that was hard to get around, so.   you decided to ruin it. Then he found  out that you were dumping water every  night. Then he was drowned.
Mr. Gittes! That's an outrageous  accusation.  I don't know what you're  talking about.
Well, Whitey Mehrholtz over at the  Times will. Dumping thousands of  gallons of water down the toilet in  the middle of a drought.  That's  news.
Gittes heads toward the door.

Wait. Please sit down, Mr. Gittes.  We're... well, we're not anxious for  this to get around, but we have been  diverting a little water to irrigate  avocado and walnut groves in the  northwest valley. As you know, the  farmers there have no legal right to  our water, and since the drought  we've had to cut them off. The city  comes first, naturally.  But, well,  we've been trying to help some of  them out, keep them from going under.   Naturally when you divert water you  get a little runoff.
Yeah, a little runoff. Where are  those orchards?
I said, the northwest valley.
That's like saying they're in Arizona.
Mr. Gittes, my field men are out and  I can't give you an exact location...
Gittes nods.
You're a married man, am I right?
Yes...
Hard working, have a wife and kids...
Yes...

I don't want to nail you. I just  want to know who put you up to it.   I'll give you a few days to think it  over. (hands him a card) Call me. I can help. Who knows?   Maybe we can lay the whole thing off  on a few big shots and you can stay  head of the department for the next  twenty years.
Gittes smiles, leaves an unsmiling Yelburton.
Gittes enters, drops his hat on Sophie's desk. Sophie tri to tell him something but Gittes goes on into his office.
Is sitting, smoking. She looks up when he enters.
What's your usual salary?
Gittes moves to his desk, barely breaking stride at the s of her.
Thirty-five bucks daily for me, twenty  for each of my operators, plus  expenses, plus my fee if I show  results.
He's sitting now. Evelyn is very pale now, obviously very shaken.
Whoever's behind my husband's death,  why have they gone to all this  trouble?
Money. How they plan to make it by  emptying the reservoirs, that I don't  know.
I'll pay your salary plus five  thousand dollars if you find out  what happened to Hollis and who is  involved.
Gittes buzzes Sophie.
Sophie, draw up one of our standard  forms for Mrs. Mulwray. (he leans back; to  Evelyn) Tell me, did you get married before  or after Mulwray and your father  sold the water department?
Evelyn nearly jumps at the question.
(continuing) Your father is Julian Cross, isn't  he?
Yes, of course. It was quite a while  after. I was just out of grade school  when they did that.
So you married your father's business  partner?
Evelyn nods. She lights another cigarette.
(continuing; staring  at her, points to  the ashtray) You've got one going, Mrs. Mulwray.
Oh.
She quickly stubs one out.
Is there something upsetting about  my asking about your father?
No!... Yes, a little. You see Hollis  and my fa... my father had a falling  out...
Over the water department, or over  you?
(quickly) Not over me. Why would they have a  falling out over me?
(noting her nervousness) Then it was over the water department.
Not exactly. Well, I mean, yes. Yes  and no.  Hollis felt the public should  own the water but I don't think my  father felt that way.  Actually, it  was over the Van der Lip. The dam  that broke.
Oh, yeah?
Yes. He never forgave him for it.
Never forgave him for what?
For talking him into building it, he  never forgave my father... They  haven't spoken to this day.
(starts a little) You sure shout that?
Of course I'm sure.
What about you? Do you and your father  get along?
Sophie comes in with the form, cutting off Evelyn's reply Gittes places two copies on a coffee table in front of Ev
Sign here... The other copy's for  you.
She signs it. When she looks back up, Gittes is staring  intently at her.
What are you thinking?
(picking up one of  copies, folding it,  putting it in his  pocket) Before this I turned on the faucet,  it came out hot and cold, I didn't  think there was a thing to it.

The engines make the small cabin vibrate. Gittes threads way down the tiny aisle of the eight passenger cabin, whi is full of middle-aged men in old clothes and their fishi gear. Gittes is poked by a pole, has to move along. One of the old men says something to him.
(above the engines) What?
You'll have to sit with the pilot.
Gittes moves forward into the cockpit, the PILOT looks up nods for Gittes to sit down, first moving a half eaten ch sandwich out of Gittes' seat.
Taxiing down the ramp into the sea. In a moment, it kicks a spray of foam and takes off.
The island gradually looming larger before the Pilot and  Gittes. The Pilot glances over at Gittes who, as usual, is impecc dressed. A contrast to the others on the plane.
(above the engines) Well, you're not going fishing.
Gittes shakes his head.
Not exactly.
(winks) But that's what you told your wife.
The Pilot laughs raucously. Gittes laughs politely.
Lots of fellas do. Tell the little  woman they're going on a fishing  trip, then shack up with some little  twist on the island... she pretty?
(abruptly) I'm going to see a man called Julian  Cross. Ever heard of him?
Is the Pope Catholic? Who are you,  mister?... I ask because he doesn't  see a whole lot of people.
I'm working for his daughter.
(surprised) That right?... She used to be some  looker.
She ain't exactly long in the tooth  now.
She must be about thirty-three, thirty- four.
You must be thinking of a different  daughter.
No, he's only got one, I remember  her age, I read it in the newspapers  when she ran away.
She ran away?
Oh yeah, it was a big thing at the  time. Julian Cross' daughter. God  almighty. She was a wild little thing.
He gives a sidelong glance to Gittes, a little concerned  he's said too much.
(continuing) Course, she settled down nicely.
(smiling a little) Well, you never know, do you?
(loosening up) That's for sure.
Why'd she run away?
Oh, you know. She was sixteen or  seventeen.
(nudging him) We missed the best of it, didn't we,  pal?
Both men laugh a little lewdly.
She ran off to Mexico. Rumor was she  was knocked up and didn't even know  who the father was. Went there to  get rid of it.
You don't say?
Cross was looking for her all over  the country. Offered rewards,  everything. Felt real sorry for him,  with all his money.

A pleasant but unobtrusive clapboard blue and white build on the bay overlooking the harbor. The seaplane lands. A  motor launch with a burgee of a fish flying from it turns and heads in the direction of the plane.

Gittes, driven in a station wagon, passes under the sign  with a cross painted below the name. The ranch itself is only partially in a valley on the isl As the wagon continues one can SEE that it is actually a  miniature California, encompassing desert, mountains and  canyon that tumble down palisades to the windward side of the sea. The wagon comes to a halt where a group of hands are clus around a corral. The circle of men drift apart, leaving J CROSS standing, using a cane for support, reedy but hands in a rough linen shirt and jeans. When he talks his stron face is lively, in repose it looks ravaged.
Walking toward the main house. A classic Monterey. A hors led on a halter by another ranch hand slows down and defe in the center of the path they are taking. Gittes doesn't notice.
Horseshit.
Gittes pauses, not certain he has heard correctly.
Sir?
I said horseshit. (pointing) Horseshit.
Yes, sir, that's what it looks like.  I'll give you that.
Cross pauses when they reach the dung pile. He removes hi hat and waves it, inhales deeply.
Love the smell of it. A lot of people  do but of course they won't admit  it. Look at the shape.
Gittes glances down out of politeness.
(continuing; smiling,  almost enthusiastic) Always the same.
Cross walks on. Gittes follows.
(not one to let it go) Always?
What?  Oh, damn near yes. Unless the  animal's sick or something. (stops and glances.  back) And the steam rising off it like  that in the morning. That's life,  Mr. Gittes. Life.
They move on.
(continuing) Perhaps this preoccupation with  horseshit may seem a little perverse,  but I ask you to remember this. One  way or another, it's what I've dealt  in all my life. Let's have breakfast.

Below them is a corral where hands take Arabians, one by  one, and work them out, letting them run and literally ki up their heels. Cross' attention is diverted by the animals from time to  time. An impeccable Mexican butler serves them their main course, broiled fish.
You know, you've got a nasty  reputation, Mr. Gittes. I like that.
(dubious) Thanks.
If you were a bank president that  would be one thing, but in your  business it's admirable. And it's  good advertising.
It doesn't hurt.
It's why you attract a client like  my daughter.
Probably.
But I'm surprised you're still working  for her, unless she's suddenly come  up with another husband.
No. She happens to think the last  one was murdered.
Cross is visibly surprised.
How did she get that idea?
I think I gave it to her.
Cross nods.
Uh-huh. Oh I hope you don't mind. I  believe they should be served with  the head.
Gittes glances down at the fish whose isinglass eye is gl over with the heat of cooking.
Fine, as long as you don't serve  chicken that way.
(laughs) Tell me. What do the police say?
They're calling it an accident.
Who's the investigating officer?
Lou Escobar  he's a Lieutenant.
Do you know him?
Oh yes.
Where from?
We worked in Chinatown together.
Would you call him a capable man?
Very.
Honest?
Far as it goes. Of course he has to  swim in the same water we all do.
Of course, but you've got no reason  to think he's bungled the case?
None.
That's too bad.
Too bad?
It disturbs me, Mr. Gittes. It makes  me think you're taking my daughter  for a ride. Financially speaking, of  course. How much are you charging  her?
(carefully) My usual fee, plus a bonus if I come  up with any results.
Are you sleeping with her? Come,  come, Mr. Gittes. You don't have to  think about that to remember, do  you?
Gittes laughs.
If you want an answer to that question  I can always put one of my men on  the job. Good afternoon, Mr. Cross.
Mr. Gittes!  You're dealing with a  disturbed woman who's lost her  husband. I don't want her taken  advantage of. Sit down.
What for?
You may think you know what you're  dealing with, but believe me, you  don't.
This stops Gittes. He seems faintly mused by it.
Why is that funny?
It's what the D.A. used to tell me  about Chinatown.
Was he right?
Gittes shrugs.
(continuing) ...Exactly what do you know about  me, Mr. Gittes?
Mainly that you're rich and too  respectable to want your name in the  papers.

(grunts, then) 'Course I'm respectable. I'm old. Politicians, ugly buildings and whores  all get respectable if they last  long enough. I'll double whatever  your fees are and I'll pay you ten  thousand dollars if you can find  Hollis' girlfriend.
His girlfriend?
Yes, his girlfriend.
You mean the little chippie he was  with at the El Macando?
Yes. She's disappeared, hasn't she?
Yeah.
Doesn't that strike you as odd?
No. She's probably scared to death.
Wouldn't it be useful to talk to  her?
Maybe.
If Mulwray was murdered, she was  probably one of the last people to  see him.
You didn't see Mulwray much, did  you?
No.
When was the last time?

Cross starts to reply, then there's the SOUND of a MARIAC BAND and some men in formation clear a bluff about a hund yards off. They are dressed like Spanish dons on horsebac For the most part they are fat in the saddle and pass alo in disordered review to the music.
Sheriff's gold posse... bunch of  damn fools who pay $5,000 apiece to  the sheriff's reelection. I let 'em  practice up out here.
Yeah. Do you remember the last time  you talked to Mulwray?
Cross shakes his head.
At my age, you tend to lose track...
Well, It was about five days ago.  You were outside the Pig 'n Whistle  and you had one hell of an argument.
Cross looks to Gittes in some real surprise.
(continuing) I've got the photographs in my office.  If they'll help you remember. What  was the argument about?
(a long pause, then:) My daughter.
What about her?
Just find the girl, Mr. Gittes. I  think she is frightened and I happen  to know Hollis was fond of her. I'd  like to help her if I can.
I didn't realize you and Hollis were  so fond of each other.
Cross looks hatefully at Gittes.
Hollis Mulwray made this city and he  made me a fortune... We were a lot  closer than Evelyn realized.
If you want to hire me, I still have  to know what you and Mulwray were  arguing about.
(painfully) Well... she's an extremely jealous  person. I didn't want her to find  out about the girl.
How did you find out?
I've still got a few teeth in my  head, Mr. Gittes, and a few friends  in town.
Okay. My secretary'll send you a  letter of agreement. Tell me are you  worried about that girl, or what  Evelyn might do to her?
Just find the girl.
I'll look into it as soon as I check  out some avocado groves.
Avocado groves?
We'll be in touch, Mr. Cross.
Dark and quiet except for the whirring of fans. Gittes  approaches one of the CLERKS at a desk.
I'm a little lost. Where can I find  the plat books for the northwest  valley?
The Clerk's droopy eyes widen a little.
Part of it's in Ventura County. We  don't have Ventura County in our  Hall of Records.
Which is a snotty remark. Gittes smiles.
I'll settle for L.A. County.
(regards him, then) Row twenty-three, section C.
The Clerk turns away abruptly. Gittes regards his back a  moment, then goes to the stacks.

Gittes sees the Clerk turn to another, say something. The second clerk gets on the phone. Gittes watches a moment,  then swiftly turns his attention to the stacks. He hauls down the northwest valley volume, opens it. It's huge and there's a lot to go through. The print itself makes him squint.

Showing TRACT, LOT, PARCEL, even a METES AND BOUNDS  designation where the description of the land parcel is l and hopelessly involved e.g. '6000 paces to Rio Seco, the 7000 paces to Loma Linda, etc.' These descriptions are ol and faded. In the owners' column, however there are numer freshly typed names pasted over the prior owners.
Hauls the huge volume back to the  Clerk's desk.
(to Clerk) Say... uh... sonny.
The Clerk turns sharply around.
How come all these new names are  pasted into the plat book?
Land sales out of escrow are always  recorded within the week.
Gittes looks a little surprised.
Then these are all new owners?
That's right.
(astonished) But that means that most of the  valley's been sold in the last few  months.
If that's what it says.
Can I check one of these volumes  out?
(quietly snotty) Sir, this is not a lending library,  it's the Hall of Records.
Well, then, how about a ruler?
A ruler?
The print's pretty fine. I forgot my  glasses. I'd like to be able to read  across.
The exasperated Clerk reaches around, rummages, slaps a r on the desk. Gittes goes back to the stacks with the ruler. He opens t book, places the ruler not horizontally but vertically.

Beside the OWNER column he places the ruler, looks toward the clerks, then swiftly rips down the page, tearing out strip about two inches wide containing the owner's name a property description. As he tears, he either sniffles or  coughs to cover the SOUND of the PAPER being ripped.

Amidst a hall of shimmering dust and heat, parched and dr groves, narrower roads. He passes a ramshackle home, next to a rotting orchard. T is a "SOLD" sign on the collapsing barn. Gittes stops, ch it against the names he had taken from the Hall of Record

And a few withered pepper trees. Gittes has paused at thi dried-up intersection. There is a "SOLD" sign on a drug s Gittes looks OFF SCREEN. Coming INTO VIEW above the arid fields is a spiraling clo of purple smoke. Gittes heads in that direction. Gittes parks at the edge of the field. About twenty yards away is a man mounted on a strange machine, holding a lid off it. Billowing lavender clouds are belching forth. Several CHILDREN are watching the man at work.
(to one of the Children) Say, pal, what's he doing?
Making some rain.
Gittes nods, walks over to the man who is elaborately bus himself with the intricacies of his machine. He's aware o Gittes watching him.
Well, you're just the man I'm looking  for.
The Rainmaker now glances down at Gittes, who as usual is immaculately dressed.
Some associates and I are thinking  of buying property out here. Of  course, we're worried about the  rainfall.
The Rainmaker steps down.
No problem with me on the Job.
Yeah. (glancing around at  the desolate, dry  field) Do you have any references?
City of La Habra Heights filled an  800,000 gallon reservoir with sixteen  inches of rain in two days.
(nods) That's swell. But how about here? (pulling out names  from his pocket) Ever worked for Robert Knox, Emma  Dill, Clarence Speer, Marian Parsons,  or Jasper Lamar Crabb?
Never heard of 'em... new owners?
Yeah.
(climbing back up) Lot of turnover these days. Better  tell them to get in touch with me if  they want to hang onto their land.
Yeah, I'll do that.

Is now covered with a film of dust: He reaches a fork in the dirt road. There are a couple of mailboxes. Gittes takes this fork and begins a slow ascent. As he does, the tops of a line of bright green trees can SEEN, coming more and more INTO VIEW, row upon row of avo and walnut groves, their foliage heavy. The few structure in the distance are white-washed, and well kept, right do to the white-washed stones that mark the pathway to the h Towering above it all is a huge wooden water tank. Gittes drives through a gate that has "NO TRESPASSING" an "KEEP OUT PRIVATE PROPERTY" signs neatly printed on it. He drives down the road into the grove.

Pulls to a halt in the road flanking the orchard lanes. H puts the car in neutral, stares at the trees. By contrast with what he has seen they are lush and beautiful, their  heavy branches barely swaying in a light breeze. Then a SHOTGUN BLAST abruptly strips bare the branches of the tree he'd been staring at.

Gittes is shocked. He looks behind him. Riding on horseba down the field in the direction he had just driven is a R Faced Man in overalls. His hat blows off his head. He doe not, however, lose the shotgun he has just used. Gittes'  lane of retreat is denied him. He guns the car, and takes off down one of the orchard lanes.

The dirt lane is rough. As Gittes nears the end of it, a  Younger Man on a mule blocks the exit. Gittes veers a sharp left, knocking a branch off one of t trees, heading down one of the cross-lanes. Here he's pur by a scraggly dog that nips at the tires. Gittes yells at it.

Two farmers on foot, one using a crutch, run down the lan toward a dust trail rising above the trees. They've spott it. Clearly it's from Gittes' car. This hide-and-seek chase between one man on horseback, on on a mule and a couple on foot continues up and down and  across the orchard lanes until Gittes' front tire and rad are ruptured by another SHOTGUN BLAST. Gittes' car veers off, scattering a stray gaggle of geese and smacks into an avocado tree, shaking loose a barrage the heavy fruit onto Gittes and the car. Gittes immediately tries to get out through the branches  over the back of his car, but he's pulled off it by one o the younger farmers, a huge brute who he begins to tussle with. The Crippled Farmer begins to bang Gittes on the ba with his crutch. The two of them manage to pound Gittes t the ground within moments, where the Crippled Farmer cont to whack away at Gittes with the crutch. The older Red Faced Farmer with the shotgun and the Man o mule ride up.
All right, quit it! Quit now! Search  the man, see if he's armed.
