Gittes is hefted half off the ground and the two younger  Farmers spin him around, going through his clothes. Gitte is badly banged up and half out on his feet. They toss hi wallet, his silver cigarette case, etc. on the ground.
I said see if he's armed, not empty  his pockets.
He ain't armed.
Gittes leans against the back of his car, breathing heavi
All right, mister. Who you with?  Water department or the real estate  office?
Gittes' back is to the Red Faced Farmer. He has trouble  catching his breath. The Crippled Farmer pokes him rudely the back with his crutch. Gittes turns sharply.
(to Crippled Farmer) Get away from me!
Answer him!
Touch me with that thing again and  you'll need a pair of them.
(shoving Gittes) Whyn't you pick on somebody your own  size?
I said cut that out! Give him a chance  to say something.
Gittes looks up at the Red Faced Farmer.
(reaching down for  his wallet) Name's Gittes. I'm a private  investigator and I'm not with either  one.
Then what are you doing out here?
Client hired me to see... whether or  not the water department's been  irrigating your land.

Irrigating my land? (exploding) The water department's been sending  you people to blow up my water tanks!  They threw poison down three of my  wells! I call that a funny way to  irrigate. Who'd hire you for a thing  like that?
Gittes reaches into his pocket. The paper's on the ground He picks it up.
Mrs. Evelyn Mulwray.
Mulwray? That's the son of a bitch  who's done it to us.
Mulwray's dead. You don't know what  you're talking about, you dumb Oakie.

The Big Farmer takes a swing at Gittes. Gittes kicks him  squarely in the nuts, knees him in the jaw after he's dou up, and hits him solidly. The Crippled Farmer takes caref aim and brings his crutch down on the back of Gittes' hea Gittes is knocked to the ground and lies still beside the Big Farmer who is writhing in agony in the dirt.
Well, that's that.
There's a PURLING SOUND, which soon becomes defined into SOUND OF VOICES talking quietly  about whether to move or not to move, doctors, etc.

Is staring down at Gittes who's lying in the screened in  porch of the farmers. His wife, the Red Faced Farmer, and the Big Farmer are there, along with the dog. The Red Faced Farmer's wife has set tea out. The farmers, all of them, now seem awkward and a little embarrassed.

head_text.subj: FRONT PORCH RED FACE FARMER'S HOUSE REACTION GITTES

text: He focuses on Evelyn who sits right next to him. He's got dried blood down the side of his face from his nose, a hu mouse on his cheek, and his clothes are torn in a couple spots.
(to Evelyn) What's going on?
(quietly, almost as  if he were in a  hospital) You didn't look too good, so we  thought we better call your employer.

Gittes nods. He checks his watch. He looks out. It's almo evening. Gittes says nothing. The wife of the Red Faced Farmer (DU looks reproachfully at Dubois. Gittes feels the back of h head, It obviously hurts him.
Evelyn and Gittes go out to her car, the cream colored  Packard. Dubois accompanies them, along with the Big Farmer who is carrying a crate of something. Gittes has cleaned himself a little.
Look here, if it's all the same with  you, we'll get your car patched up.  If you'll tell me what your trousers  run you, I'll make good on them, Mr.  Gittes.
It's okay, Mr. Dubois.
(to Evelyn) It's just that they're after everybody  out here, tearing up our irrigation  ditches trying to make our land  worthless so they can pick it up for  twenty-five dollars an acre.
Gittes nods.
(continuing) Anyway. Earl here is sorry, too. He  wants to give you something to take  back with you.
Gittes looks. Earl has the huge crate he's holding brim-f of avocados.
Thanks, Earl.
Evelyn driving.
Thanks for coming...
Gittes pulls out cigarette case, takes one, offers one to Evelyn who refuses.
That dam is a con job.
What dam?
The one your husband opposed. They're  conning L.A. into building it, only  the water won't go to L.A. It'll go  here.
The Valley?
Everything you can see, everything  around us. I was at the Hall of  Records today. (whips out papers,  turns on the car  light) That bother you?
No.
(looking over papers) In the last three months, Robert  Knox has bought 7,000 acres, Emma  Dill 12,000 acres, Clarence Speer  5,000 acres, and Jasper Lamar Crabb  25,000 acres.
Jasper Lamar Crabb?
Know him?
No, I think I'd remember.

Yeah. They've been blowing these  farmers out of here and buying their  land for peanuts. Have any idea what  this land'll be worth with a steady  water supply? About thirty million  more than they paid.
And Hollis knew about it?
It's why he was killed. Jasper Lamar  Crabb. Jasper Lamar Crabb.
He's pulling out his wallet, excitedly now, spilling its  contents onto the seat. He pulls out the obituary column  he'd folded up earlier in the day.
(continuing) We got it. We got it, baby.
What? What is it?
There was a memorial service at the  Mar Vista Inn today for Jasper Lamar  Crabb. He died three weeks ago.
Is that unusual?
Two weeks ago he bought those 25,000  acres. That's unusual.

head_text.subj: EXT. MAR VISTA INN AND REST HOME NIGHT

text: Evelyn's car pulls up before the elegant Spanish rest hom its entryway illuminated by streetlights. There is a smal sign giving the name of the place in elegant neon scroll. sits on the rolling green lawns. Gittes gets out of the car with Evelyn. He offers her his arm and they go up the walkway to the entrance.

head_text.subj: INT. MAR VISTA INN AND REST HOME NIGHT

text: Gittes and Evelyn are approached by an unctuous man in hi forties, with a flower in his buttonhole. He sees Evelyn  first.
Hello there, I'm Mr. Palmer. Can I  help you folks?
Then he gets a clear look at Gittes, bruised, trousers to etc.
Yes, I sure hope so. It's Dad. (indicating his  disheveled appearance) I just can't handle him anymore, can  I, sweetheart?
Evelyn shakes her head.
Oh my goodness.
(hastily) Nothing to do with Dad. It's me,  actually.
They just don't get along very well.  Dad's a lamb with anyone else.
(not so sure) Oh, well, I don't know.
Naturally, I want the best for him,  money is no object.
Perhaps if we could meet your father.
There's just one question.
Of course.
Do you accept anyone of the Jewish  persuasion?
Evelyn can't quite conceal her surprise at the question.
(very embarrassed) I'm sorry. We don't.
(smoothly) Don't be sorry, neither does Dad.  Wanted to make sure though, didn't  we, honey?
Evelyn stares back at Gittes, amused and appalled. She ma to nod.
Just to be certain, I wonder if you  could show us a list of your patients?
(polite but pointed) We don't reveal the names of our  guests as a matter of policy. I know  you'd appreciate that if your father  came to live with us.
Gittes locks eyes with Palmer.
(confidentially) That's exactly what we wanted to  hear.
Oh, good.
I wonder, is it too late for us to  have a look around?
I don't think so. Be happy to show  you.
Would you mind if we took a stroll  on our own?
Just, if you will, confine yourself  to the main building. It's nearly  bedtime.
We understand, c'mon, sweetheart.
He takes Evelyn.

Looking. Either by accident or design, the primarily  octogenarian guests have segregated themselves. In one wi the men are playing pinochle, some are playing dominoes, elderly gentleman sits by himself carefully peeling an or In an adjacent parlor several white-headed ladies work on quilt. Gittes grabs Evelyn's hand.
(quietly) They're all here. Every goddam name.

Gittes points to the wall. It says "ACTIVITIES BOARD". Th are titles. "LAWN BOWLING". "BRIDGE". "FISHING". "CROQUET Below them are the names of the guests, entered under cer activities, for certain days. After Evelyn looks, she turns to Gittes.
(continuing; indicating  the ancients around  them) You're looking at the owners of a  50,000 acre empire.
(astonished) They can't be.
They may not know it but they are.
Gittes strolls toward the women knitting and working on t quilt.
Hello, girls.
Two of the ladies giggle. The third continues to busy her with her quilt, off by herself.
(continuing) Which one of you is Emma Dill?
Two of them say "she is," and point in different directio The third gives them a curt look and goes back to her  knitting. Gittes approaches her.
Are you Emma?
Some old voice is singing softly, "Don't Sit Under the Ap Tree."
Yes.
I've been wanting to meet you.
Why?
Did you know that you're a very  wealthy woman?
(stitching, smiles) I'm not.
Well you own a lot of land.
Not anymore. Oh, some time ago, my  late husband owned a good deal of  beach property in Long Beach, but we  lost it.
Gittes looks at the quilt. In it is the head of a fish am the rest of the crazy quilt pattern. Gittes spots it.
That's just lovely.
Thank you...
He looks through the quilt for other pieces of the fish,  comes across the tail and by it the initials A.C.
(indicating tail) Where did you get this material?
(what it sounds like) The apple core club.
The apple core?
No. The albacore. It's a fish. My  grandson's a member and they take  very nice care of us.
How do they do that?
Give us things. Not just some old  flag like this, but -
(kneeling) But what?
We're a sort of unofficial charity  of theirs, Mr. Gittes. Would you  care to come this way? Someone wants  to see you.
Gittes looks up, sees Palmer standing in the doorway, loo taut and a little drawn. Evelyn is beside him. She gestur as if there's someone behind Palmer. Gittes rises.
See you later, Emma.
He walks toward Palmer who waits for him to walk in front
Is waiting. He's got his hand in his pocket. Evelyn looks Gittes. The four of them stand there, Mulvihill towering over  everyone.
Come on I want you to meet somebody,  Gittes.
(glancing from Palmer  to Mulvihill) Can we leave the lady out of this?
(a little uncertain) Yeah, why not?
Okay, I'd like to walk her to her  car.
I'll stay.
(taking her by the  arm) Get in the car.
I'll see she makes it.

Mulvihill has walked up beside Gittes. He makes the mista of opening the glass door in the entryway, putting his ba to Gittes for a moment. Gittes swiftly pulls Mulvihill's  jacket up over his head. He spins him around. With his ja covering his face, Gittes hammers away at Mulvihlll, beat him against the glass door, along the wall, mercilessly  pounding his fists into the cloth until the cloth turns r and Mulvihill begins to sink to the red tile floor. Palmer screams. Evelyn stands there astonished. Mulvihill gun has clattered to the floor.
(as Mulvihill hits  the floor, to Evelyn) What are you waiting for? Get in the  car!

Evelyn goes. Mulvihill tries to get up again. Palmer starts to go for gun, nearly picking it up. Gittes slaps it out of his han and kicks it. It goes flying down the hall, at least thirty feet; hits wall. Palmer goes screaming off into the night. Gittes turns ba to Mulvihill who starts to get up, then collapses. Gittes goes out the front door, ignoring the excited audi of ancients behind him.

As Gittes walks down the pathway, he stops. Two men are c toward him. One of them is shorter, and has the nervous,  jerky moves of the man who slit his nose. Gittes stops. The two men fan out and continue to move to him. Gittes spots the two-tone shoes. He begins to back up. Suddenly there is a pair of headlights flashing brilliant behind the two men. In a moment Evelyn's car is headed ac the lawn directly toward the two men, accelerating as it  gets near them. They look in disbelief, then dive for saf The car skids to a stop, fishtailing a little on the gras Evelyn opens the passenger door.
Get in.
Gittes jumps in and she takes off across the lawn, tiltin the elegant little neon sign on the lawn as she goes. Two SHOTS ARE FIRED.
Evelyn looking straight ahead, driving. After a moment sh takes one hand off the wheel and rubs her left eye a litt Gittes watches her. He smiles.
Gittes stands on the veranda, smoking a cigarette, starin off into the night. Evelyn comes out to the veranda, carrying a tray with whi and an ice bucket on it. She sets it down. Gittes turns.
(watching her pour) Maid's night off?
Why?
(a little surprised,  he laughs) What do you mean, 'why?' Nobody's  here, that's all.
(handing Gittes his  drink) I gave everybody the night off.
Easy, it's an innocent question.
No question from you is innocent,  Mr. Gittes.
(laughing) I guess not to you, Mrs. Mulwray.  Frankly you really saved my a... my  neck tonight.
They drink.
Tell me something. Does this usually  happen to you, Mr. Gittes?
What's that, Mrs. Mulwray?
Well, I'm only judging on the basis  of one afternoon and an evening, but  if that's how you go about your work,  I'd say you're lucky to get through  a whole day.
(pouring himself  another drink) Actually this hasn't happened to me  in some time.
When was the last time?
Why?
Just. I don't know why. I'm asking.
Gittes touches his nose, winces a little.
It was in Chinatown.
What were you doing there?
(taking a long drink) Working for the District Attorney.
Doing what?
Gittes looks sharply at her. Then:
As little as possible.
The District Attorney gives his men  advice like that?
They do in Chinatown.
She looks at him. Gittes stares off into the night. Evelyn has poured herself another drink.
Bothers you to talk about it, doesn't  it?
Gittes gets up.
No. I wonder... could I. Do you have  any peroxide or something?
He touches his nose lightly.
Oh sure. C'mon.
She takes his hand and leads him back into the house.

Gittes pulls the plaster off his nose, stares at it in th mirror. Evelyn takes some hydrogen peroxide and some cotton out o medicine cabinet. Evelyn turns Gittes' head toward her. S has him sit on the pullman tile adjacent to the sink.
Doctor did a nice job...
She begins to work on his nose with the peroxide. Then sh sees his cheek, checks back in his hair.
(continuing) Boy oh boy, you're a mess.
Yeah.
(working on him) So why does it bother you to talk  about it... Chinatown...
Bothers everybody who works there,  but to me... It was...
Gittes shrugs.
Hold still. Why?
You can't always tell what's going  on there.
...No. Why was it.
I thought I was keeping someone from  being hurt and actually I ended up  making sure they were hurt.
Could you do anything about it?
They're very close now as she's going over a mouse very n his eye.
Yeah. Make sure I don't find myself  in Chinatown anymore. Wait a second.
He takes hold of her and pulls her even closer,
(momentarily freezing) What's wrong?
Your eye.
What about it?
(staring intently) There's something black in the green  part of your eye.
(not moving) Oh that... It's a flaw in the iris...
...A flaw...
(she almost shivers) ...Yes, sort of a birthmark...
Gittes kisses her lightly, gradually rises until he's sta holding her. She hesitates, then wraps her arms around hi

On a nightstand, city lights visible through the open win behind it. It is RINGING. Evelyn's arm reaches INTO SHOT. SOUND of something hitting the headboard. Gittes moans. VIEW SHIFTS TO INCLUDE Gittes in bed, holding his head, w he's just hit. Evelyn pauses in her reach to the phone. S turns to him, whispers, "I'm sorry," kisses him on the he and lips. PHONE CONTINUES TO RING. She picks it up.
Hello... (in Spanish now) No, no, I'll come and help, just  keep watching her and don't do  anything until I get there... 'bye.
VIEW SHIFTS AGAIN TO INCLUDE Gittes in bed, watching Evel next to him as she's talking on the phone. She hangs up. touches Gittes' cheek lightly.
I have to go.
Gittes stares at her silently.
Where?
Just... I have to.
And I want to know where.
(she starts out of  bed) Please don't be angry... believe me,  it's got nothing to do with you.
(stopping her) Where are you going?
(near tears) Please!... Trust me this much... (she kisses him lightly) I'll be back. Look, there is something  I should tell you. The fishing club  that old lady mentioned, the pieces  off the flag.
The Albacore Club.
It has to do with my father.
I know.
He owns it. You know?
I saw him.
(sitting up straight) You saw my fa... father? When?
This morning.
(panicked) You didn't tell me.
There hasn't been a lot of time.
She leaps out of bed, throwing on a robe.
What did he say? (insistent) What did he say?
That you were jealous, and he was  worried about what you might do.
Do? To who?
Mulwray's girlfriend, for one thing.  He wanted to know where she was.
Evelyn starts quickly for the bathroom, then comes back a kneels by the side of the bed, takes Gittes' hand.
I want you to listen to me. My father  is a very dangerous man. You don't  know how dangerous. You don't know  how crazy.
Give me an example.
You may think you know what's going  on, but you don't.
That's what your father said. You're  telling me he's in back of this whole  thing?
It's possible.
Including the death of your husband?
It's possible. Please don't ask me  any more questions now. Just wait,  wait for me. I'll be back. I need  you here.

She kisses him, rushes to the bathroom, shuts the door. G stares at it a moment. Then leaps out of bed, rummages ar tosses on his trousers. He grabs his shoes, throws them o Then hurries out of the bedroom.
Running across the driveway to the garage. There are two  cars there. Mulwray's Buick and Evelyn's Packard. Gittes moves over to the Buick, opens the passenger's doo
Checks the ignition. No key is in it. He pulls a couple o wires from under the dash, starts to mess with them, seem satisfied. Slides out across the seat, slams the door.

Gittes hurries over to the Packard. He gets down on the  driveway, lying on his back, bracing himself. With the he of his shoe, he kicks at the right rear taillight of the  car. He shatters the red lens, gets up. He carefully pull the red lens off the taillight, exposing the white light  beneath it. He tosses the red lens into the shrubbery and hurries back toward the house.
Evelyn's car speeds along the curves on Sunset Boulevard, the red and white lights coming IN AND OUT OF VIEW.
Behind the wheel of Mulwray's car, keeping a healthy dist from Evelyn in front of him.
Pulls up before a small little bungalow house. She gets o looks up and down the street. There is nothing. She hurri on up the walkway to the front door.

head_text.subj: DOWN THE STREET GITTES IN BUICK

text: Idles the engine with the lights off. He brings the car a few yards further down the street, parking it near Evelyn Gittes gets out of the car and goes up the walkway. The  curtains are drawn except for one of the small windows on the side of the house. He goes to it and looks, balancing on the edge of the por
Gittes sees Evelyn's Oriental servant rush through the li room of the small house. In a moment he re-emerges back  through the living room carrying a tray with a glass and  pitcher on it.

Around to the side of the house. He runs into shrubbery a a short picket fence. He climbs over it, follows along the stucco wall to a ser of windows at the corner of the house. These all have sha on them. He can hear someone crying in the house. Someone else tal alternately firmly and plaintively in Spanish. Here the  windows have blinds. He moves to one where the blind is n completely drawn. There's an inch or so of space at the bottom.

Gittes can see the servant again. Evelyn is pacing back a forth in and out of his line of vision. After a moment so rises INTO SHOT, obviously from lying on a bed. The figur is just a few feet from Evelyn. Her tear-stained face com INTO VIEW. It is unmistakably the girl Gittes had last se with Hollis Mulwray. Mulwray's girlfriend. She's looking up to Evelyn, speakin in Spanish. Her words are not discernible but the tone is bitter, anguished. A newspaper is strewn about the room. Evelyn kneels. She insists that the girl swallow down som pills. The girl reluctantly does.
Continues to watch.
Emerges from the house, goes to her car and gets in.
Evelyn sees Gittes sitting in her car, staring coldly at  her.
Okay, give me the keys.
(stunned, furious) You bastard.
It's either that or you drive to the  police yourself.
The police?
C'mon, Mrs. Mulwray. You've got your  husband's girlfriend tied up in there!
She's not tied up!
You know what I mean. You're keeping  her there against her will.
I am not!
Then let's go talk to her.
Gittes starts to get out of the car. Evelyn grabs his arm nearly screaming:
No!
Her intensity actually rips Gittes' already partially tor jacket. He looks at it and her. It seems to have a momentary calm effect on both of them.
(continuing) She's too upset.
What about?
Hollis' death. I tried to keep it  from her, I didn't want her upset  before I could make plans for her to  leave.
You mean she just found out?
Yes.
That's not what it looks like, Mrs.  Mulwray.
What does it look like?
Like she knows about Hollis' death.  Like she knows more than you want  her to tell.
You're insane.
Gittes explodes.
Just tell me the truth. I'm not the  police. I don't care what you've  done. I'm not going to hurt you, but  one way or another I'm going to know.
You won't go to the police if I tell  you?
I will if you don't.
A long pause. Evelyn's head sinks onto the steering wheel her hair covering her face.
She's my sister.
Evelyn is breathing very deeply now. Not crying, but the  kind of deep breathing that comes from real hysteria. Git puts an arm on her shoulder.
Take it easy... If it's your sister  it's your sister... why all the  secrecy?
She lifts her head and looks up at him. He's genuinely  puzzled.
(really upset) I can't...
Because of Hollis? Because she was  seeing your husband? Was that it?  Jesus Christ, say something. Was  that it?
She nods. Gittes sighs.

(finally) I would never ever have harmed Hollis.  I loved him more than my own family.  He was the most gentle, decent man  imaginable... and he put up with  more from me than you'll ever know...  I just wanted him to be happy...
She begins to cry softly.
(after a moment) I took your husband's Buick... (he opens the car  door) I'll return it tomorrow.
Aren't you coming back with me?
Don't worry. I'm not telling anybody  about this.
...That's not what I meant.
There is a long moment of silence. Gittes looks over to  Evelyn. Her hair covers most of her face from him.
(finally) Yeah, well... I'm very tired, Mrs.  Mulwray. Good night.
He gets out and slams the car door. She drives off.

The spray is hitting him full on the top of the head. Git is so exhausted he's literally holding onto the nozzle as the water pours down. He shuts the shower off, reaches we for a towel, dabs his nose lightly with it.

Pads around in elegant silk pajamas. He walks over to the window where morning light is stream in. He closes the curtains, collapses on the bed, on top the covers, inert. Almost immediately the PHONE RINGS. Gi lets it go on for a moment, then picks it up without sayi anything.
(male) Gittes?... Gittes?
Yeah.
Ida Sessions wants to see you.
Who?
Ida Sessions, you remember Ida.
Gittes slowly rises to one elbow.
Yeah?... I do?
Sure you do.
Well, tell you what, pal. If Ida  wants to see me she can call me at  my office.
He hangs up, falls back down. PHONE RINGS AGAIN. AND AGAI Gittes swears, picks it up.
684 1/2 East Tensington. Echo Park.  She begged me to call. She's waiting  for you.
Before Gittes can say anything, the phone clicks dead.

head_text.subj: EXT. CERRITOS TOWER ROAD HOLLYWOOD HILLS EARLY MORNING

text: Gittes pulls up. It is a bungalow courtyard with a very n walkway and sickly green stucco.
Gittes at the front door. It's slightly ajar. He knocks.  Nothing. He opens it and enters.

Morning light filters through the half-open blinds. Dust  particles in the shafts of light. It's still and empty. G sees something down the hall, under the legs of a telepho table. Gittes moves toward it. It is grotesque. When he g closer he can see it's a wilted head of lettuce. Just ins the kitchen some radishes and onions lie on the linoleum. Gittes walks on into the kitchen.

Clearing the kitchen counter, Gittes sees IDA SESSIONS ly on her back on the floor, surrounded by the groceries fro broken bag. Ice cream has melted around her. Her eyes are open, a str of ants is moving across the ice cream and into her mouth She's recognizable as the woman who posed as Evelyn Mulwr Gittes kneels over her. He gingerly opens her handbag, fi for its contents, takes them and looks at them on the kit counter. Wallet with a few bills in it, driver's license with her  name. A Screen Actors Guild card. Gittes nods, turns,  carefully replaces the items in the purse. He idly opens the broom closet, pantry, and even Frigidai which is all but empty. Then he steps over her body and m across the hall to a door that is slightly ajar.
Gittes enters and turns on the light.
Find anything interesting, Gittes?

Escobar and another PLAINCLOTHED MAN stand in the bathroo by the entrance to the bedroom door. Gittes turns around. THIRD MAN is now coming down the hall from the bedroom. Gittes looks at the two, doesn't reply.
What are you doing here?
Didn't you call?
(jerk of his head  toward the kitchen) How do you happen to know her?
I don't.
(turning toward other  room) Let me show you something.
Escobar points to the number "MU 7279" on the side of one the kitchen cabinets.
Isn't that your number?
Is it? I forget. I don't call myself  that often.
Just to be on the safe side, we had  Loach here give you a ring.
He indicates one of his assistants.
(a slight sneer) What happened to your nose, Gittes?  Somebody slam a bedroom window on  it?
(right back, smiling) Nope, your wife got excited, crossed  her legs a little too quick. You  understand, pal.
The Assistant starts to move for Gittes who is ready for  him. Escobar steps between the two.
(to other Assistant) Loach. (Escobar pulls out a  drawer) How about these? Look familiar?
In the open drawer are the photos of Mulwray and the girl the park, boat, and at the El Macando on the veranda.
(no point in denying  it) Yeah, I took 'em. So what?
How did she... (meaning the corpse) ...happen to have them?
Gittes takes a deep breath.
Either you tell me or I guess 'cause  I don't have the answer.
Escobar nods.
You really think I'm stupid, don't  you, Gittes?
I don't think about it one way or  the other. But if you want, give me  a day or two, and I'll get back to  you. Now I'd like to go home.
I want the rest of the pictures.
What pictures?
(meaning the corpse) This broad hired you, Gittes, not  Evelyn Mulwray.
Yeah?
Yeah. Somebody wanted to shake down  Mulwray, she hired you, and that's  how you happen to know Mulwray was  murdered.
I heard it was an accident.
C'mon, you think you're dealing with  a bunch of assholes? Mulwray had  salt water in his goddam lungs! Now  how did he get that... in a fresh  water reservoir?
Gittes is surprised at this piece of information, but rem nonplussed.
You were following him night and  day. You saw who killed him. You  even took pictures of it. It was  Evelyn Mulwray. She's been paying  you off like a slot machine ever  since her husband died.
(smiling) You accusing me of extortion?
Absolutely.
I don't think I need a day or two.  You're even dumber than you think I  think you are. Not only that, I'd  never extort a nickel out of my worst  enemy, that's where I draw the line,  Escobar.
Yeah, I once knew a whore who for  enough money would piss in a  customer's face, but she'd never  shit on his chest. That's where she  drew the line.
(smiling) Well, I hope she wasn't too much of  a disappointment to you, Lou.
Escobar manages a thin smile.
I want those photographs, Gittes.  We're talking about accessory after  the fact, conspiracy, and extortion.  Minimum.

Why do you think Mulwray's body was  moved you dimwit? Evelyn Mulwray  knocked off her husband in the ocean  and thought it would look like more  of an accident if she hauled him up  to the Oak Pass Reservoir?
This is a little telling.
(continuing) Mulwray was murdered and moved because  somebody didn't want his body found  in the ocean.
And why's that?
He found out somebody was dumping  water there. That's what they were  trying to cover up by moving him.
This stops Escobar. He's dumbfounded by it.
What are you talking about?
C'mon I'll show you.
Escobar hesitates.
(continuing) C'mon make a decision, Lou. You're  in charge.
The men around Escobar look to him. Escobar grudgingly no

It yawns AT CAMERA, only a trickle of water dropping into the ocean. VIEW WIDENS TO INCLUDE Escobar, Gittes, and two Plain  clothesmen, standing and staring at the empty pipe as if  they expect it to talk.
(squinting in sunlight) It's too late.
Too late for what?
They only dump the water at night.
A THIRD ASSISTANT runs down the side of the cliff and Ove to Escobar.
Reach anybody?
Yelburton, he's the new chief.
I know who he is. Well?
He says -
I know what he says.
(to Gittes) Shut up. (to Assistant) Go on.

Yelburton says they're irrigating in  the valley. There's always a little  runoff when they do that. And he  says is Gittes knows that, and has  been going around making irresponsible  accusations for the last week.
Escobar turns to Gittes. Stares at him for a long moment.
Let's swear out a warrant for her  arrest. What are we waiting for?
(meaning Escobar) Because he just made lieutenant, and  he wants to hang onto his little  gold bar.
Escobar stares hatefully at Gittes.
Have your client in my office in two  hours and remember. I don't have to  let you go. I've got you for  withholding evidence right now.

Gittes in Mulwray's Buick whips into the driveway. He loo in the garage. Evelyn's car is gone. Only the Gardener's  truck is there. Gittes hurries along the pathway and up to the house. He  rings the doorbell. Scarcely waiting for an answer he tri it. It's locked. He reaches into his pocket pulls out his cigarette case,  takes a pick out of the side and starts to fool with the  lock. The Maid opens the door abruptly, stares in some surprise Gittes.
Where's Mrs. Mulwray?
No esta.
Gittes looks past the Maid to the center of the living ro where luggage is packed and neatly piled. The Maid is actually in the process of throwing covers ov the furniture.
(indicating luggage) Is Mrs. Mulwray going someplace?... (no answer) on a trip?... vacation?...
No esta in casa.
Gittes nods. He continues through the house and out back the veranda.
